author: {'steamid': '76561197981631970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1709067623}
review:
To put the negative things first: Yes, Sunset's tech is a bit wonky. I have a four year old middle class PC and, boy, does the framerate break down when I put the resolution up to 4k. Even if it's from 2015, look, it's a Unity game made by a small team. Optimization wasn't probably high on the list, getting it out of the door before the Kickstarter funds ran out was maybe the higher priority. And to be clear: I'm not mad about this! Making games is hard! Problems happen in development and that's okay. 

Let us focus on the good things: If you love Walking Sims like Gone Home and Dear Esther, Sunset is for you. If you love the kind of weird art games Tale of Tales did before, Sunset is very much for you. It's slow, it takes time and there's a lot of things the game tells you is happening, but you won't see. It's not afraid of having a politicial position. If you roll your eyes about american imperialism, well, I don't know, go play Call of Duty instead. 

The graphics are relatively simple, but the art direction shines so much through the whole game. The whole 70s vibe and a lot of hidden details show how much the devs loved Sunset's setting. 

I love how subtle my choices can influence the story. There's probably bunch of things I have missed that I will gladly seek out on a second playthrough. 

Sunset is not for everyone. But if you're okay with some technical disadvantages and slow burn narrative games, I think you will like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045796166', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1680161582}
review:
Sunset é um jogo narrativo de primeira pessoa criado pelo estúdio belga Tale of Tales. O jogo foi financiado pelo Flanders Audiovisual Fund e por uma campanha no Kickstarter que tinha US$ 25.000 como meta e atingiu US$ 67.636 em apenas um mês. 

A protagonista é uma afro-americana chamada Angela Burnes, que está trabalhando na limpeza de um apartamento de luxo de um artista famoso chamado Gabriel Ortega, num país fictício chamado Anchuria, onde ocorre uma guerra civil. Ao longo do jogo, as ações da personagem podem alterar o rumo da história ao influenciar o pensamento de Ortega. Burnes foi inspirada por Angela Davis, Pam Grier e Nina Simone, além da experiência pessoal de Aureia Harvey, da Tale of Tales, como expatriada americana. 

O apartamento no qual o jogo se passa é baseado no "apartamento ideal" de uma edição de 1970 da Playboy e no apartamento de Yves Saint Laurent em Paris. A história foi parcialmente inspirada pelo filme coreano de 1994, Chungking Express.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1700560364}
review:
Sunset is a narrative driven adventure game dressed up like a job simulator where you work as a housemaid in 1972 during some political turmoil.  There's some potential in the concept but ultimately, this is a poorly written story, told poorly. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game features lazy minimalist/untextured low-polygon "retro" assets and visuals, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the early 1990s.  While initially it might look tasteful, this appearance drops away sharply when you see trees sticking out of the floor in the various apartments you visit... like, not in a pot, the developer was too lazy, they just poke out of the floor, or hover slightly above it.  Fail.  The lack of textures is a method that lazy devs often use to disguise their lack of talent/interest in doing the graphics properly and trying to disguise it under the name of "art", or "We made it look bad on purpose", which really isn't something gamers should have to put up with.  It's unclear why the developers weren't willing to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets and high resolution textures for the game.  It looks bad as a result of their decisions, and that's just another reason to avoid it.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's an almost healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this only appears around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Sunset has the pathetically optimistic price of $20 USD, for which you could easily get any number of older AAA games.  That's an eye watering price that exceeds the price of games like The Witcher 3 and the entire Mass Effect Trilogy.  This is also competing with over 9,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.  Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061981262', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1696866153}
review: I enjoyed this. It's relaxing and chill. I enjoyed the atmosphere of the apartment and it was fun to explore. I never got bored, in fact, I will probably soon play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198997412844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1690783107}
review: I feel bad saying this because I quite enjoyed The Graveyard as a comedy piece (I know that's not what they intended). This is the worst game I've ever played. This is a game about not doing or experiencing anything. You have chores to do in the same house every day, but the game cuts to a loading screen before cutting back to the chore having been done. There's constant talk of a war outside, but you take no part in it. Your character thinks about the war while you walk around looking for the next loading screen. Every chore has Y or N depending on what area your reticle is on, Y is correct and furthers the game and N just makes the game shorter I think. The characters are weird and the story is complicated and disjointed. It's told through post it notes and thoughts, and you can sit down in specific spots occasionally for more monologue. Also you can accidentally skip a day which messes things up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081293192', 'num_games_owned': 4734, 'num_reviews': 3864, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1465385921}

author: {'steamid': '76561198142182090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1689296980}
review:
I can understand both the positive and negative reviews of the game itself and the concept.  But I'm incredulous that more people didn't say "oh by the way the optimization SUCKS!".  I mean is that not the deal-breaker here?  

I've gotten through a few hours of this game (somehow) and I personally enjoy it just enough to give a (somewhat hesitant) thumbs-up.  But the stilted animation throughout is straight crazy.  Granted my computer is four years old but it is I7 & RX 580...and this game came out four years before that!  I didn't even mind lowering the graphical settings, except that didn't help!  It's just bizarre that this makes it to the marketplace (and I don't mean to single out this one, lord knows there are others...that Rapture game comes to mind, it is also nearly unplayable on my PC, but to be fair they were going for a higher graphical standard.  Though lowering the settings on that didn't help either!  Ethan Carter also had framerate problems.  I dunno, I can play stuff like Outlast, Edith Finch, and Overwatch on high settings without a single hitch.  Sunset does have a very interesting art style but the quality is like Dreamcast level stuff ffs!  How is this not running smoothly? (like I said I lowered the levels, and lowered them again, and again...)

Of course I've heard about the rash of terrible top-tier PC ports, but I wasn't aware that it extended to walking simulators from the 2010s..  The conclusion is that this issue all but ruins a game.   If my middling computer specs can't handle something, then I'm totally cool with that, bc that's on me.  But otherwise (and in the games I've mentioned) it's developers releasing a program that cannot properly perform, and that's a little scary.  Seriously, just go read Giant Bomb's article about Sunset, he illustrates my point WAY better than I did. 


  
(PS lol in case you were wondering I been playing these walking games on doctor's orders, due to a hand injury...Edith Finch is pretty mind-blowing, and Firewatch was a lot of fun to play...the main difference is the former has an incredible ending and the latter has a non-existent one)

author: {'steamid': '76561198093913293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1710566653}
review:
A very solid and unique game, with lots of options to adjust your gameplay experience. But it's not the best it can be.
The biggest selling point, other than the setting and art direction, is that it's slightly an immersive sim.

Time is always moving, the sun is always setting. They way the city lights turn on, and the colors and shadows change as you play is really well done, and the amount of little things you can find for Angela to give her thoughts on or effect the story help fill the space of free time.

However, it's a very linear game. You're only exploring the same apartment. It's changing each level, but you'll find many rooms locked off each time, which hurts replay value for the exploration and experimentation on limited time.

Haven't finished it yet, but for its gameplay design and what you get each level, it's not worth 20 bucks.
Get it on sale, like how I got it for 4 bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964496918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1687925251}
review: The game started off as "idk what to do", expected of someone constantly exposed to "gamey games pew pew", so the UX is a bit unintuitive at first, but I found myself being gripped by the setting and scenario. The choices will influence scenarios in the game. For example, I'm a thirsty housekeeper flirting with my client in the midst of a violent revolution, without actually seeing him. Sweet. Ooorrr you could also play it cool and leave the relationship professional. Either way, the devs continue to explore creative storytelling in their games, in this case, a development of a relationship under this unfortunate circumstance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032081632', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1432422874}

author: {'steamid': '76561198425716483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1662123049}
review:
有一段时间每天上完课后第一件事就是打开Sunset，经常玩着玩着Mac电脑就会变得很烫手，偶尔甚至会闪退，也就是在这时，窗外的夕阳斜斜地照在电脑屏幕上，一时间整个房间内都是缓缓晃动着温暖的光。Sunset营造出的独特氛围至今都让我不断地回味着。
sunset是这样的一段时光，辛勤的忙碌之后，一天已经要结束了，但似乎也只有这时，属于自己的一点时间才开始流淌。
Sunset在设计上是很简略的，全程也只能看到自己的倒影，主要的推进都体现在了文字和空间的变化上，也因此留下了想象介入的空间，我认为可以说这也是一款很色情的游戏了吧。

author: {'steamid': '76561198032718700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1671196692}

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198075513382', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1659750950}
review:
Es gibt Walking Simulators & "Art Games" die mir gefallen, z.B. "Gone Home", aber das hier war nichts.
Man spielt eine schwarze Amerikanerin die in den 1970er Jahren ihr Glück in einem fiktiven Südamerikanischen sozialistischen Utopia sucht und dort als Haushälterin für einen Reichen arbeitet.
Hierbei besteht das ganze Spiel daraus, dass man mit einem Aufzug in die Wohnung fährt und dann einige Aufgaben zu erledigen hat, danach verlässt man das Haus mit dem Aufzug, nächster Tag und es geht so weiter.

Wäsche waschen, Tisch decken und so was.
Nebenbei erfährt man nur über Monologe der Protagonisten über die politischen Unruhe und das immer repressiver werdende Regime, die im Land vor sich gehen.

Teilweise hört man von der Terrasse zur Straße raus marschierende Soldaten, man sieht fliegende Helikopter und brennende / bombadierte Häuser.
Das ganze ist unglaublich repetitiv und in den 3 - 4 Stunden passiert absolut nichts.
Das wäre zu verzeihen, wenn es wie etwa in "Everybody's gone to the rapture" wenigstens viel zu entdecken gäbe, aber die wenig detalierte Low Level Grafik bietet das nicht.
Da sich das ganze Spiel in einem Haus abspielt, gibt es kaum eine Soundkulisse, mit Ausnahme von Schallplatten die man gelegentlich findet.
Es gibt viele Achievements, die man bekommt, wenn man unterschiedliche Bücher, die in der Wohnung verteilt sind, reinzoomt.

Technisch hatte ich auch einige Probleme, wie verzerrte Perspektiven, bei Spiegelungen der Protagonistín in Spiegeln und Fenstern.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027480202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1659175420}
review:
Tale of Tales has made some incredibly innovative interactive art over the years; "The Path" and "Fatale" are among my favorite experimental gaming experiences, and I thought "The Endless Forest" was a breath of fresh air in a genre that rarely changes. I still mourn what "8" could have been; it was for "Sleeping Beauty" what "The Path" was for "Red Riding Hood". 

I feel "Sunset" continues this trend of singular interactive narrative's; it took me a long time to work my way back to it, but it resembles aspects of Tale of Tales' entire history as a studio as much as it doesn't. Every day feels purposefully mechanical, and resembles the anxiety of real life in crisis to a large degree as one attempts to move forward with their responsibilities while it seems as though the world is ending. I became addicted to these minor idiosyncrasies very quickly, compelled forward in discovering as many texts or events as I could to elaborate on the world outside the apartment beyond the balcony. In working through these tasks, as mundane as they can be, they teach you the layout of the home and ask of you to notice subtle changes. As far as the tasks, usually cleaning or building objects, you do have choices as to how you approach them; with optimism, or cynicism, and alongside that, you have the ability to respond to notes Gabriel Ortega leaves in the apartment in a similar fashion. It's reminiscent of Firewatch, but far more subtle, although I don't know whether that's a good or a bad thing. The space you have to wander, at the very least, is much more claustrophobic and that feels crucial for this experience in which people feel trapped underneath a militaristic existence.

I knew nothing, and I'm glad that was the case, because it had its greatest potential as a resonant experience in being an enigma.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313119867', 'num_games_owned': 1056, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1654544648}

author: {'steamid': '76561198321598085', 'num_games_owned': 482, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1639875176}
review:
I don´t recommend this game to everyone. I don´t recommend it especially to those who expect action and/or fast progression from the game. Sunset is pretty minimalistic and slowgoing game and there definitely is restricted amount of interactions with the enviroment. But all those aspects are more about personal preferences rather than quality of the game.
I believe the game offers very meaningful gameplay.
The point is to return to the same but always different apartment with the main character, observe the changes that tells us the story of the life of it´s inhabitant. At the same time, we do small changes here and there and with them we can send messages, often unverbal, to him. We also uncover the story about the town and listen to thoughts of Angela about art, war and society.
The artstyle of the game is very beautiful, following design art of the previous century, and the changes in lighting throughout time progression are pretty impressive too.
For those who may enjoy collecting, this aspect is added through search for the books, scattered through the house - each of them adding achievement.
I would reccomend playing the game in various sessions. That way, you feel more like you are returning to the apartment together with the protagonist. Trying to play through in one session could strip you of this experience.
My only critique concerns lags I experienced from time to time for no apparent reason on my side.
Overally, I really enjoyed the game, it felt chilling and thoughtful. Slow building of the relationship between characters that never met and uncovering the story of the enviroment you can see just from the window was pleasant experience for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198877713872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1684610170}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053212872', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1642351560}
review: This is the third-best Tale of Tales experience after [i]Luxuria Superbia[/i] and [i]The Graveyard[/i], a meandering journey through musings on art, wealth, conflict, culture, and so on, told through the eyes of a housekeeper. Some aspects of the plot and setting seem dubious; for example, Mr. Ortega is rich and an avid reader, so why are so many of his books cheap paperbacks? Then there's Angela; I [i]really[/i] want to know more about her, as her background and circumstances sound incredible, especially when compared to her mundane job. Still, the game has interesting things to say, the plot goes to some equally interesting places, and Mr. Ortega has impeccable taste in art. There are some wonky controls, cutting through the dining room becomes arduous after a certain point, and the total number of achievements is excessive, but it generally plays fine. The diary feature is handy as well. Not for everyone, but if you've enjoyed other Tale of Tales works and/or arty games in general, this is worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034132429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1587139580}
review:
[h1] Биеннале Tale of Tales [/h1]
Мне очень нравятся игры Tale of Tales, но Sunset поначалу принесла разочарование. Однако со временем, чуть лучше ознакомившись с современным искусством (я всё ещё во многих вопросах профан, но всё же), я стал ближе к пониманию замысла разработчиков.
Если вы ждёте самой игры - её нет, как и в других играх студии. Если вы ждёте какую-то невероятную подачу, которая была в других играх студии - её здесь тоже не очень-то много. Зато есть много геймплейной рутины. Есть даже какой-то выбор - наша альтер-эго может выполнять свою работу уборщицы с любовью, а может и с ненавистью к классовому врагу. Выполнено это очень топорно, хоть в редкие моменты и цепляет. Но как игра оно того не стоит - лучше идите и купите Gone Home. Здесь вечеринка для другой аудитории.
Я рекомендую эту игру тем, кто хочет посмотреть на современное искусство, но не имеет возможности поехать в какой-нибудь арт-центр на биеннале. Биеннале - это такие выставки, которые проводятся раз в два года. И вот Sunset очень похожа на часть такой выставки, но с гораздо более объёмной, я бы сказал, с грандиозной идеей, которую бы выставка всего этого вживую провалилась бы по ряду технических причин. Обычно представленная на таких фестивалях инсталляция малоинтерактивна и не меняется или слабо меняется со временем, и уж тем более не учитывает поведение каждого посетителя. Для Tale of Tales пространство особняка - это арт-центр, который дали разработчикам на растерзание и который готов меняться изо дня в день, из часа в час. Каждый игровой день - новая инсталляция, новые книги и предметы эпохи, новая записка героини в дневник. Но есть в игре и то, что не может сделать уважающий себя арт-центр по этическим соображениям - арт-обстрел (кажется, в таких местах пишут "sic!") города. А ещё там красивый тропический лес за разбитой стеной.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124457598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1640312729}
review:
I ended up liking the game. It does draw on a bit much. I think having to sit down in a chair to learn more about your character. Gets very mundane after a while... 

This game almost give me a Alfred Hitchcock Rear Window vibe. However there are so many limiting factors in this story. Your sort of presented the chaos of the revolution developing outside the apartment. But that can only be so interesting. When you don't have anything but "explosions", sounds of gunfire, smoke, and the occasional helicopter, jet passing through. Also there is a character that is sort of thrown in to the story. That has an odd feeling to it?

 I think the game would of been a little better with it's pacing. If it had condensed it's main character's narration into a journal that you can CHOOSE to read from. That may impact the delivery of the tone of the story for whomever doesn't pay as much attention. But that does clear up plenty of time. And room to possibly address that? 

Aside from the pacing being the most critical issue. I think the main character is well developed. The fictional country and events surrounding it feel all too real. The music is Fantastic. Was always excited to play the next record. Finding books, observing the art pieces were all very pleasant, and educational. 

The Graphics are pretty good. But there was a stuttering issue with the frame rate. Not sure why that occurs? I think this game is the best piece of work they've developed by far. They said there not going to work on games anymore. So I guess you could say this is their magnum opus. 

If your a patient person with walking simulators, and like discovering bits here, and there. I definitely recommend this. The story is pretty alright. The more you play it. A tone starts to develop, which I think is phenomenal. Play it in small portions. Maybe that helps with the pacing? Game is already short. Just under six hours for me.

EDIT: I found articles relating to the studio's closure. Where some of the creators of this title lashed out at it's audience. An a offensives, aggressive manner. As an artist you should never criticize your audience. Whether they are interested or not. Is completely up to them. It's your job as an artist to observe these positive, and negatives criticisms. And grow from it. 

It's frankly insulting to be that rude. And put's a stain on this piece that could easily be admired by people in time. I hope the one's involved realize the lack of wisdom, foresight, and respect towards anyone, and or themselves. Have felt sincere regret towards those statements. 

Perhaps those insults have allowed them to grow. An a different direction than if they didn't say anything? 

SPOILERS!!

I observe a similarity between these creators public outcry's. And that of the protagonist/antagonist? Angela Burnes act's in a very destructive manner at some point in the story. And she definitely shows a feeling of remorse/regret. And wonders if she had truly made the right choices in her life?

author: {'steamid': '76561197961768818', 'num_games_owned': 4045, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1638246243}
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/9686972/]Follow "[b]First Person Exploration and Puzzle Games[/b]" for more games like this![/url][/quote]

This game is [i]worlds[/i] better than the previous walking simulators by this dev.  I applaud their efforts to improve. But this is still not a good game.

The game works like this: you're a maid, hired to clean an expensive apartment while the owner is away.  Every day you're given a list of tasks to do around the apartment. While cleaning, you learn about the owner, and record your thoughts about the semi-fictional world.  As someone who loves games like Gone Home, this sounds like a great concept to me.

Unfortunately, the implementation is extremely poor:

• The explorable area is more-or-less the same every day. The optional interactables seemingly do nothing aside from contributing to some achievement, meaning there is no reward for exploration. Exploration is one of the most important parts of any walking simulator, and they [i]completely[/i] botched it.

• The things you learn about the owner are not interesting (at least for the time I played), and are few-and-far-between.

• The actual cleaning steps involve staring at a short loading screen, which is annoying.

• There is a time-limit which is not conveyed well to the player. When you exceed it, you're forcibly ejected from the apartment, even if you haven't completed your tasks or were in the middle of a monologue.

• The [i]"record your thoughts about the world"[/i] monologues can only be heard by sitting in a specific chair of the dozens in the apartment.  This is not hinted at AT ALL in the game, meaning it's very easy to miss. You're not able to listen to them while exploring, meaning you'll be staring at the screen and twiddling your thumbs while listening. And to top it all off, they just give background that is both uninteresting and seemingly irrelevant to the rest of the story.

Overall, unless you're really interested in a "cleaning simulator", I think this one can be skipped.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054794643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1638025726}
review:
Sunset is not for everyone.
Not sure how to categorize it, but i'd rather call it an artsy exploration game than a walking simulator. You'll walk a lot, but most of all you'll be searching for the right items. 

Basically you're in the role of a housekeeper for a wealthy guy in the 1970s, and you do daily tasks like tidying up, sorting stuff, cleaning and ironing clothes. Here and there you'll have to furnish something, like placing carpets at the right place or hanging picture frames...

While you work on your daily list of duties, you'll get to roam the owners' apartment, and while doing that you'll find books and personal items that tell you a bit more about his life and background.

Not all areas of the apartment are always accessible, some doors are only open at certain days, so you'll have to keep an eye open not to miss anything. 

After doing the tasks for a day, you're going back to the elevator and click to continue to the next day, where you'll get a new list of chores.
This can get tiring and many days feel almost the same without big changes going on. I guess it was intended to show a realistic (boring) daily job routine? 

After a while your boss starts leaving you notes, if you react to them, it will somewhat influence the story. 

What i really liked about the game were the really nice colour expressions and artsy design of the apartment, the music and the voice acting. 
It's a great game to relax and take screenshots. 

What i didn't like is, that on some days the chores are not exactly clear, so you basically have to roam around in the apartment and search for an item you can interact with to do the task.  
That can get boring and annoying, but yet again, maybe it was intended to show a realistic impression of a housekeepers' life. 
The story is transmitted in tiny bits every day and can be hard to follow, near the end i still wasn't exactly sure what's even going on. 

The game has a lot of achievements, and these give you a good overview of all the (story) items that you've seen or missed after one play through. 
It took me about 7 hours to complete the game once, but i've only collected 50% of the achievements, so i'll have to play it again someday. 

[h1]Overall, i liked for its unique experience, but yeah, before you consider buying it, you'll have to be aware that the game is extremely slow paced and probably really boring for the average player.  It's artsy and relaxing, a little mysterious, but most of the story is rather subtle and needs to be uncovered. If you're up for it, i'd recommend getting it on sale for 4,99 or less.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197983869611', 'num_games_owned': 1651, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1637868196}
review: Sunset es un juego peculiar. A través de tareas más o menos cotidianas, que van desde planchar la ropa hasta recoger cristales rotos, podremos conocer tanto a nuestra protagonista como a su jefe. Con decisiones muy sutiles, que tomaremos a la hora de llevar a cabo estas tareas domésticas, además, podremos darle un carácter distinto a nuestra protagonista. Todo ello con una guerra civil de fondo, que nos hará sentir auténtica impotencia por momentos. Un título distinto, con una capacidad casi misteriosa para atraparte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198873388908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1634323793}
review:
I understand why many people dislike this game. But personally, I love it. Even if it gets repetitive and far too long for its own good (and it definitely does), it just feels so great wandering around the house, taking in the atmosphere, the art and the music. Even the sappy romance doesn't ruin it. 

I guess I just like games that are not very good.

Edit (10.08.2021): ToT sure like their fairytales / myths retellings: their most famous project is based on Red Riding Hood, another one of their games is based on the legend of Salome, and they also planned a Sleeping Beauty game called 8, but things happened. I kinda get the feeling that this game was initially planned to be a retelling of Beauty and the Beast / Eros and Psyche, but then they decided to make the game more... let's say politically relevant, only leaving one brief reference to Eros and Psyche. Which is a pity, because, while the game would definitely work as a fairy tale retelling, it definitely doesn't work as a 'realistic' story about a dictatorship and a rebellion in 1970s Latin America. 

Fairy tales don't have to make sense, at least, not the normal kind of sense; but when the game is trying to tell me a meaningful story about a far right dictatorship, the plight of African-Americans, capitalism, socialism and American (neo)imperialism, I'm kind of entitled to wonder why an important official within said dictatorship hires a housekeeper without ever bothering to meet her in person (how would that be even possible in the pre-Internet world?); why they start flirting through notes and environmental clues without even knowing how the other person looks; why the housekeeper is so attracted to him despite being so resentful of her lot; why she doesn't seem to have any other jobs or responsibilities, yet doesn't even try to save her brother or look for a non-housekeeping job (if she's rejected from other jobs, we're never told); and what's the big deal about leaving his house before sunset, anyway. 

If you look at this as an Eros and Psyche retelling, it all makes sense, but the game was never marketed as such.

author: {'steamid': '76561198384790422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1685342108}
review: I loved Sunset. This game follows the daily chores and quietly subversive acts of a maid in a war torn country. While the game takes place entirely in a single penthouse apartment, I found the story utterly compelling. Through Angela's narration, subtitled inner thoughts. notes back and forth to her employer and her diary entries, the player follows a story of political upheaval happening in the outside world. Most evenings, the apartment is bathed in orange and purple sunset colors, though as the story progresses, you begin to see terrifying scenes of a burning city and bombs dropping through the huge penthouse windows. Inside the apartment, you can make choices about how to respond to your boss Gabriel Ortega's notes and how to interpret his list of chores. These choices affect how your relationship with Gabriel progresses, although you never see him in person. The apartment is filled with art -- Gabriel Ortega is an art collector, and collects more and more work as the game progresses -- and Angela reflects upon these works as she cleans. Throughout the apartment are various record players, and the soundtrack to this game is breathtaking, adding a beautiful ambiance to the already gorgeous environment. This is very solidly a walking sim game. It is a contemplative, slow burn, which is something that I love, but it may not appeal to players who prefer more action and conflict.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996859750', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 396, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1594328654}
review: Really nice walking simulator/first person narrative-exploration game, with a unique setting. It was really satisfying getting to know the owner of the house, the protagonist and the social context in which the game takes place, little by little each day. It looks beautiful, it's well written and has excellent music. If you like those "artsy" games from Tale of Tales, you'll like it for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205558200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1463366205}
review:
"Sunset" is a pretty chill game about a young woman tasked with cleaning/taking care of the home of a client with interesting historical and political affiliations.

I mainly stay in the psychological horror genre, so this was a nice departure from what I'm used to playing. Although, some portions of this game WERE creepy, but then again, I may have been looking into things too much, lol. I guess there is just something about being in a significantly-sized home. Alone. 

I enjoyed viewing the changing scenery and learning more about Mr. Mysterious. 

Each day, you are presented with various tasks you must complete in order to "pass" that level. I did feel a bit rushed throughout my days, because you ARE on a timer. I would have loved to do more exploration and take my time with certain things, but, hey, at the end of the day, this is how the game was created.

The graphics are beautiful, and I truly enjoyed listening to the main character's voice. It had a soothing effect on me, and it may do the same for you as well.

If you're into house simulations/explorations, housekeeping, politics, reading, and history, this may be an interesting game for you. Over the span of a few days (actual real-life days, versus the days I am talking about in the game), the gameplay became a bit repetitive, and I slowly retreated from "Sunset" and back into the night-tinged world of psychological horror. 

My rating: 6/10 newspapers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285559759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1595279289}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004054459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1434969224}
review:
not recommended

the creators did not deliver what was originally described on the gofund me page for this game, as it turned out it was just a walking similator doing chores around a house with inner monologue. as the original description for the game insinuated that you play a key role in Espionage being the house keeper.

"It's 1972 and a military coup has rocked Anchuria, a small country in Latin America. As a result, you, Angela Burnes, US citizen, are trapped in the metropolitan capital of San Bavón. Your paradise has turned into a warzone. To make ends meet, you take up a job as a housekeeper. Every week, an hour before sunset, you clean the swanky bachelor pad of the wealthy Gabriel Ortega. You are given a number of tasks to do, but the temptation to go through his stuff is irresistible. And what is he up to? As you get to know your mysterious absent employer better, you are sucked into a rebellious plot against the notorious dictator who rules the country with an iron fist." but  sadly it had no intresting plot elements just boring inner monologue of the character while doing errands, so imagine "papers please" about just doing paper work and no other plot points about helping the resistance etc

i personally had high hopes for the small indie dev and as a fan of thier previous works like THE PATH, LUXURIA SUPERBIA,but sunset was a let down

author: {'steamid': '76561198123990817', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1641516196}
review:
It is a sad thing this might be the last time we get to enjoy Tale of Tales craft. Sunset is an interesting and beautiful experience. The performance was given to bring to life to Angela Burns really captivated me as much as the game environment of the story. 

The game could be major with minor tweaks in tech and some environmental details outside of the penthouse complex but besides that, the game does a serviceable job in making its simple gameplay slightly addicting to a slow burn of a thriller and will stick with me.

I will definitely recommend this gamer to friends, even if they don't find the game fully intriguing but I will say to them to just give a chance. 

If Tale of Tales never comes back, I hope its legacy brings a new wave of more interesting and beautiful experiences as Sunset, The Path, and others never finish but promising An Empty World and The Book of 8.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057042299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1666367046}
review:
Inizio a giocare e l’unica cosa che posso fare è pulire la casa di un ricco critico d’arte, in un paese in preda alla rivoluzione, mentre mio fratello mette bombe per la città, contro lo stesso critico, asservito al regime.

Nel mezzo mi siedo e ragiono sull’arte, sulla politica. Rubo informazioni, giro per l’appartamento, ne vedo i cambiamenti nel corso dei mesi.

Leggi i biglietti che il datore di lavoro mi lascia, scrivo i miei. Non ci siamo mai incontrati. Mentre lavoro metto su degli LP di musica sudamericana, jazz. Osservo l’architettura d’interno anni settanta, terribile.

Penso. Vedo i giorni che passano, i santi del calendario cattolico, le assunzioni in cielo. Nove ore di gioco in una ambientazione tra il 1972 e il 1973 per entrare nel videogioco che, per Tales of Tales, doveva essere il gioco per i giocatori e che invece si è rivelato un insuccesso commerciale tale da indurre i due programmatori a fare dell’altro (ambienti artistici in VR, se ho capito bene).

Dal punto di vista del gameplay Sunset è un “gioco” sbagliato. Per tantissimi motivi. Come ci si può appassionare ad un gioco nel quale interpretiamo una ragazza nera che ha lasciato gli Stati Uniti e ora fa la donna delle pulizie dalle cinque alle sei di sera, una volta alla settimana? E il gioco è – apparentemente – questo, fare le pulizie.

E anche dal punto della progettazione 3D Sunset non convince: i bellissimi colori, la grafica funzionale fanno a pugni con una programmazione che rende gli spostamenti faticosi e il rendering decisamente troppo lento.

Il fatto è che Sunset è piuttosto un’opera di letteratura elettronica, sotto il vestito del videogame. Un’opera di letteratura elettronica che ha anche ambizioni dal punto di vista grafico/artistico. Un’opera tutt’altro che banale, che vive attraverso simboli, riti, luoghi, lettura, suoni (tantissimi suoni) e musica. Un’opera talmente coinvolgente, se si ha voglia di essere coinvolti, e io l’ho avuta, dicevo, tanto coinvolgente che ad un certo punto ho iniziato a cercare su Amazon i libri della biblioteca del protagonista per comperarne uno.

Per poi scoprire che era inesistente, faceva parte di questa America latina alternativa, inventata ma assolutamente credibile.

Quando la rivolta arriva in città, prendono fuoco i palazzi, e la settimana dopo arrivano gli aerei degli Stati Uniti per dare manforte al regime, beh, è un romanzo, è fiction. È politica.

Alla fine il videogioco termina, scorrono i titoli di coda, le decine e decine di persone che hanno lavorato per il progetto e poi, inaspettatamente (un bug?) è ancora possibile restare nel gioco. Rimanere dentro, girare in tutte le stanze dell’appartamento, vederle per l’ultima volta.

E il finale, spoiler, devo dire che sono due o tre giorni che mi è rimasto dentro. Gioca tutto su un simbolo, su un colore, mi aspettavo una fine narrativa e invece tutto è dentro un luogo, un tempo, un colore  che abbaglia e fa risuonare l’appartamento che per tutto le precedenti nove ore avevo visto solo nel rosso fuoco del tramonto. Lo sfondamento della civiltà e il ritorno della natura, del vuoto e dei rumori della natura.

Alla fine, Sunset è una delle cose migliori che abbia incontrato ultimamente.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993841729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1596835186}
review: An interesting exploration of a constrained space, and a space which changes based on decisions you make over the course of the game; Ortega's apartment starts to feel like a home, as both he and Angela make their mark on it. The story is compelling, and the way it's told and the sound design both do a good job of making you feel like it's happening around you. My only real criticism is that if you're taking the time to engage with everything, the game takes a bit longer than it needs to in order to do what it's doing. I'd recommend it if you're looking for the kind of story that doesn't often get told in games, however.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993647588', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1478532154}
review: The latest and, if their recent tantrum is to be believed, the final Tales of Tales game which has you playing a sort of housemaid for an important figure in the political landscape of a South American country teetering on revolution. You've got an in-game hour each day to spend in your boss's house either carrying out the list of chores he leaves or just doing your own thing; with other optional tasks to be discovered as you explore the house. The plot of the revolution plays out via a combination of your character's musing and notes that you and your employer leave for each other. The latter allow you to develop a relationship with the unseen Ortega and depending on the responses you choose this can be romantic in nature. So, a novel idea that's mostly well implemented but it suffers from ToT's usual refusal to explain themselves very well. It took me a while to even realise that most of the actions have two different variations you can choose from because getting the cursor to switch between the options is often a total fucking pain in the arse. Similarly, you can apparently encourage you character to keep a diary to flesh out the plot if you sit in a particular chair which I don't think was ever explained (or, if it was, I was able to miss it entirely) and I only even realised when poking around in the options after finishing the game. The visuals and audio are general very good, though there's hitches in the performance that affected me quite badly. If you like this kind of indie weirdness in general, and you have a high tolerance for pretension, then this is worth looking at but it's definitely a very flawed thing.

review:
Στα [-]
•  Βλακώδης, βαρετή καί από κάθε άποψη αποτυχημένη προσπάθεια περιγραφής μιάς λαικής εξέγερσης εναντια στό αυταρχικό καθεστώς κάποιας φανταστικής Λατινοαμερικανικής χώρας. 

Συνοψίζοντας
•  Οι αρτιστικοκουλτουριάρικες εμπνεύσεις τής Tale Of Tales δέν κατάφεραν ποτέ νά προσεγγίσουν τήν ουσία τών adventures, παραμένοντας σέ μιά σχέση χρησιμοποίησης/εκμετάλλευσης παρά προσφοράς.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995627577', 'num_games_owned': 841, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1539611542}
review:
Sunset is a game about war. In the same way that All Along the Western Front is a book about war. If you would like to reflect on the impacts, horrors and confusions of war, I recommend this game.

This game is not like many other games. Some people have compared it to Gone Home, but I think Gone Home is too coherent for that. This isn't a bad thing. It is the difference between a poem about an apartment, left up to interpretation, and a story about a house, which still has interpretations, but is more clearly about an arc. I think this is more similar to The Beginner's Guide. I consider this experience to be an "emotional sandbox" game. More generally, it is a kind of living poem, like other Tale of Tales games. The power of this game is to get you to ask emotional questions about your character and her actions. When the bombs are dropping, do you update the calendar? Is that because that's all you have control over?

A note, the game does not seem particularly well optimized, and I had a few troubles with the controller I was using, but in the end it worked fine on my computer, and the beauty shines through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335998281', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1534972113}
review:
First of all, i recommend this game only because there is no neutral mark on Steam (i hate it honestly)  so i recommend the game only for 2-3 reasons.
I always had hard time playing Tale of Tales games. They are too user unfriendly and i dislike developers 'cause they were this "You're all bad and you don't understand my works" people. There are a ton of niche and indie games that are leagues above any of their works. 
I always thought and will be thinking that the only truly decent game they made was The Path. I played Graveyeard, Fatale and now Sunset. And unlike Graveyeard and Fatale Sunset wasn't complete disappointment and actually had some well done parts.
The game tells you a story about young housekeeper Angela who works on Gabriel, a powerful politican in the country. Gameplay is all about you cleaning the house and making some other stuff such as cooking. The interesting thing is how you can do this things,  with love and passion or without and how Gabriel will treat you depends on it.  That's what you should know without spoiling anything
And my opinion about the main story. It's boring in many ways. I can say that 60% of the game was boring for me and especially cleaning the house part because i just couldn't find many obvious things. And overall the plot isn't that great. But it had some moments that made me respect the game. [spoiler]It's when the window exploded and Angela's brother died. And final level, i think. The window explosion was the best part in my opinion. It managed to show me a little bit how terryfing revolution and civil war can be. I was shocked because that's exactly how it happens. You don't expect anything until in one day BAM and everything is changed forever[/spoiler]
In every other way except the story the game is bad. Bad optimisation (was lagging as hell), grpahics and animation though it's understandable (Tale of tales went bankrupt after release of the game) and bugs. I can surely say i can't really recommend you the game but if you like arthouse games and indie then maybe(MAYBE) you can try this one. I only managed to play it one time even though devs say that the game has high replayability.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1533279541}
review:
"Sunset" ist ein First-Person Story-Erkundungs-Adventure.

Eine Warnung vorweg: dieses Programm ist sicher nicht für jeden. Der durchschnittliche Gamer wird wahrscheinlich nichts oder nur wenig damit anfangen können, denn es folgt nicht den Regularien, die normalerweise für Spiele gelten. Einfluß auf die Ereignisse hat man praktisch nicht und man selber ist eigentlich auch gar nicht der Protagonist. 

Wir schreiben das Jahr 1972. In unserem fiktiven, aber deutlich an mittel- oder südamerikanische Länder erinnernden Land greift das Chaos immer mehr um sich. Die Lebensverhältnisse werden immer schwieriger, die Regierung führt mit harter Hand, Rebellen versuchen die Regierung zu stürzen und die Macht an sich zu reißen.

Ein Szenario, daß eigentlich für actionreiches und dramatisches Gameplay taugt. Direkt an der Front zu sein oder in leitender Funktion auf einer der beiden Seiten zu führen bietet sich an, "Sunset" macht aber genau das nicht, sondern geht auf komplette Gegenteil.

Wir sind Angela Burnes, eine junge Frau, deren Leben sich nicht so entwickelt wir gehofft. Die wirtschaftlichen Probleme haben dazu geführt, daß wir nicht mehr in unserem eigentlichen Job arbeiten können. Stattdessen müssen wir putzen gehen und einer unserer Kunden ist Gabriel Ortega, ein hochrangiges Regierungsmitglied. Einmal pro Woche putzen wir seine Wohnung. Dabei treffen wir ihn nie persönlich, überhaupt treffen wir niemanden. Wir sind lediglich lediglich für eine Ingame-Spielstunde alleine in seiner Wohnung und haben bestimmte Aufgaben. Den Müll runterbringen etwa oder aufräumen. 

Ein unspektakuläreres Setting kann man sich kaum ausdenken. Wir erfahren über alles was passiert in den Zeiten der Rovolution nur aus zweiter Hand, aus Zeitungen, die rumliegen, aus Notizen unseres Auftraggebers, aus der Anwesenheit der Hubschrauber, die über der Stadt kreisen.

Wir lernen unseren Auftraggeber im Laufe der Zeit, auch wenn wir ihm nicht begegnen, besser kennen. Er scheint in Korruptionsvorwürfe verstrickt, ist aber auf der anderen Seite ein kunstversierter Feingeist. Er läßt Kunstobjekte in seine Wohnung bringen, um sie vor der Zerstörungswut der Rebellen zu schützen; das behauptet er zumindest. Im Laufe der Zeit entwickelt sich eine Beziehung zwischen der Protagonistin und dem Wohnungsinhaber und je nachdem wie wir auf seine Post-it Notizen antworten, kann sich diese kühl oder intim werden.

Zwei Seelen wohnen nämlich in unserer Brust. Zum einen wissen wir, daß sich was ändern muß, daß soziale Gerechtigkeit durchgesetzt werden sollte; zum anderen sind wir doch von der Intelligenz unseres Auftraggebers fasziniert. Allein seine Lektüre, die wir immer wieder finden zeigt seine soziologisch und künstlerisch ausgerichtete Seele. Andererseits wiederum ist unser Bruder, für den wir viel Sympathie empfinden immer aktiver bei den Rebellen.    

Wir gehen also in die Wohnung und putzen ein wenig, finden dabei aber im Büro eine Top-Secret Akte. Sollen wir sie ignorieren, sollen wir sie den Rebellen faxen?

Und dabei haben wir, trotzdem es ein paar Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten im Spiel gibt, eigentlich nicht wirklich Einfluß auf das Geschehen. Die Revolution wird sich entwickeln wie sie sich entwickeln wird. Ohne unser Zutun. Ohne Macht, es irgendwie wirklich zu beeinflussen zu können. 

Diese Perspektive der Hilflosigkeit, diese Position des Betrachters von außen, ist ein wichtiger Bestandteil von "Sunset". Es wird nichts direkt erzählt, auch was mit der Hauptfigur außerhalb des Putzjobs passiert, spielt kaum eine Rolle. Jeder Tag, jede Runde startet im Aufzug, von dem aus wir die Wohnung betreten. Dann räumen wir ein wenig auf, finden Notizen, klimpern ein wenig auf dem Flügel rum und verlassen die Wohnung wieder, nur um gleich auf eine Woche später zu springen und wieder aus dem Aufzug zu steigen, um eine Wohnung zu putzen.

Diese Setzung macht "Sunset" zu etwas Besonderem, Außergewöhnlichem, aber auch zu etwas schwer Verdaulichem, wenn man denn ein Spiel erwartet. Für mich ist diese Stimmung, diese erschreckende Hilflosigkeit aber eine große Stärke, etwas was die Situation in einigen Momenten erstaunlich real spürbar macht.

Trotz der ästhetischen Souveränität hat das Programm doch einige deutliche Schwächen. Merkwürdig und unverständlich erscheint, daß wir jeden Tag immer nur bestimmte Räume, meist die, in denen es auch etwas zu machen gibt, betreten können. Die anderen sind einfach dicht. Das verhindert zwar viel Umhersuchen, wirkt aber auch reichlich unpassend und alles andere als immersiv. Schade auch, daß unsere Aktionen, ob nun putzen oder Bilderaufhängen, nicht wirklich erlebt werden, sondern lediglich der Befehl gegeben wird und dann die Zeit übersprungen wird. Merkwürdig auch, daß wir immer nur genau eine Stunde Zeit haben und dadurch manchmal nicht zu allem kommen, auch wenn es nur wenige Minuten über der Zeit wären.

Die Grafik ist technisch eher simpel, manchmal fast abstrahiert, dafür weiß der Entwickler mit starken Farben und Lichtstimmungen umzugehen, die teils auch geschickt die Farbverliebtheit der 70er aufnehmen und reflektieren.

Dafür ist der Sound und die Musik stark. Die Sprecherin trifft Stimmungen gekonnt und immer wieder können wir uns Platten aus der Zeit, oft hochqualitative Jazzwerke, die aber deutlich außerhalb des Mainstreams liegen, auflegen. 

"Sunset" ist gemacht von Intellektuellen, von Künstlern, die eine für mich spannenden und neuen Zugang zu historischen Ereignissen gefunden haben, es ist erwachsen, es ist hochreflektiert. Aber es ist eigentlich kein Spiel, es gibt nicht wirklich ein klares Ziel zu erreichen, trotz Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten bleiben die Auswirkungen unklar, es gibt auch nicht wirklich Negativkonsequenzen, wenn wir Mechaniken nicht ausführen.

Eigentlich ist "Sunset" eher ein arthaus-Film über den Zusammenbruch einer Gesellschaft, ein Kunstprojekt, das uns zwar in die First-Person-Perspektive versetzt, uns aber dann aus dieser heraus nur eine entfernte Draufsicht auf die Geschichte liefert. Ein intelligentes Experiment, bei dem man aber die Bereitschaft mitbringen muß, sich darauf einzulassen.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
9/10 Atmosphäre
9/10 Story
7/10 Grafik
9/10 Sound
5/10 Spielmechanik
-/10 Balancing
7/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Alles andere als Mainstream.

[h1][b]8/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1643043763}
review:
Tags: Adventure - WS - Creative Walker
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Narratively disjointed. Incohesive audio and text assets at times. Easter egg, pixel hunt in small recycled environment.

Engine feels like Unity. The WASD controls with mouselook works. Dev added a variety of useless options such as independent XY axis sensitivity, a 2.5D mode that makes you instantly nauseous. Window would sometime flicker, such as when using telescope, losing the crosshairs and replacing it with a pointer that was not in sync with the game.

Progression is handled by going up and down the elevator. You may complete cleaning tasks, and you may sometimes open sort of easter egg eye candy for the appartment. Later on the narrative will undo most of it however so no point in getting zealous. The game does not keep track of what tasks you do or not so a good rule of thumb is to hunt for them in case they fire a script, such as an explosion outside but more often than not they are simply crossed out and nothing happens. Later in the game it becomes frequent for the tasks to become trivial or even outright absent from the list. Finding what the tasks refer to exactly and where to find the interactable piece to complete it can sometimes be a bit of a pain and I would routinely fail to find some after circling what seemed like the entire appartment multiplet imes. Progression of time is very uneven from instance to instance. Time fast forwards when interacting with a hotspot, so in some instances you will run out of time and be evicted basically while on other occasions with few hotspots you can run around forever and barely any time passes. Ultimately however the game does not actually restrain you from progressing and you can even summon the elevator from pressing the ESC key which is probably the lesser of two evil given how unengaging this aspect of the game can be. 

Narratively and in terms of characterization the game makes little sense, going from treating the appartment as a haven, to it being vandalized, to then treat it like an unknown safe haven again. Sometimes text assets will show a seemingly caring housekeeper's thoughts while the audio clip playing shows a plotting characterization filled with tension so when those clash it is never a good look on the dev. The main character in terms of personal development does very little, and passively influences the narrative at most. 

The actual idea of having a sandbox with easter eggs set in a cool setting with a ton of exposition and lore works for me however. I have seen this concept used time and time again in RPG's and open world action games. You have a stronghold or someplace you call home and you get involved decking it out and if there are scripts you can trigger in it to open areas of the game or new abilities all the better. But here you do not have an open world to go out and see. All there is is basically the player's home, and the world out there is not very well characterized, only through the voice blurbs and the occasional letters do you learn anything. Even then it is through the very subjective and sometimes seemingly self conflicting lense of the main protag that you are fed your game world setting. It leaves you with very little to actually fill the blanks with in the theatre of the mind and renders the experience more shallow as a result.

Conclusion: While I appreciate the casualization of their title this is just not a rewarding experience. Other than get emotionally distraught, often fail to clean an appartment and generally be miserable while the world seemingly slides into anarchy there is little at all happening here. They did not even bother making each day and instance engaging on its own, even if only out of respect of the player's time. Instead they tacked on a 30 min real life wait of just letting the engine sit there with no hotspot to fast forward things so that you can in theory meet the landlord that you had until then never seen. I ended up going to smoke and missing the little voiced blurb for it. Tale of Tales just... were playing around with some ideas, but this whole black panther's american graduate housekeeper maid in a south american country that sounds like it came out of Papers Please while the art loving landlord both is a revolutary intellectual and a shrewd businessman that sells arms to the goverment. There is just... a lot of material, but they do not do anything with it. It is only a millenial simulator in unity engine, cry, whine, seethe against the world, think yourself a crusader, fail to clean after yourself. While more ambitious than The Graveyard or Fatale, this is still one of the subpar Tale of Tales titles. It was nice not getting stuck, but in terms of narrative ease, it is not much better than hunting for hotspots in The Path. While the narrative was less cryptic and did not rely on keeping you guessing it failed to fleshen up. Devs officially claimed to be done with the industry but have been heard from since but I have by now played all Tale of Tales products and I must say that the entertainment value is more often than not simply too absent to really warrant given the original concepts the benefit of the doubt. I would not blame anyone else but themselves and would try to learn the lessons from their failures if they want to make a good product that will actually achieve much more than whatever they produced here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1523129436}
review:
I'm surprised  I got to the ending of this game ... 3.4 hours later. It felt a lot longer than that. I have no idea what this game is after playing it from start to finish. You go in the same room each and every single darn time. You do menial tasks. In the late game, you do exactly the same thing over and over and over and over again. You are tasked with putting the mail on the dining table and pressing a green button that opens a door somewhere. Opening the door really just means finding the open door and then clicking on some random stuff that makes time go faster.

Except you don't even need to do that. Do you even need to do anything in this game? The story is progressed by your character, Angela Burnes, talking to herself about the events. You'll also see the city scape change with explosions, screaming, gun fire, as a civil war is breaking out. Yet you continue to clean this guy's penthouse. 

Does being a maid for a rich dude in a mostly empty penthouse sound fun to you? That's 90% of this game. I usually like walking simulators but this one is a cautionary tale on how NOT to do a walking simulator. The story is slow and plodding and the interactions are dull and boring.

So you're not really part of the revolution, although you do some helpful things. Your boss plays a bigger role after seemingly being part of the system. And you fall in love with each other? WTF? You never see each other. I never felt any tension. I have no idea how Gamespot gave this game a 7/10 or how Metacritic has this as a 66/100.

Rate 2/10. One of the worst games I have ever played from start to finish. I kept believing there was more to the game. You'd suddenly become a bigger part of the revolution. You'd stop cleaning. Instead, you're upset because your boss may be in trouble as you're in love with him ... seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158252329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1114, 'last_played': 1520884003}
review:
I don't understand why I had to really really complete this game all the way down to the ground. I mean, I even wrote a guide for it- my first one ever.

Maybe because of how I started off playing the game. On my old computer, which is getting a new hard drive, wasn't top of the line. Just a plain old dell PC from 2012 or 2013 I dunno. Got the game as a gift {Shout out Frrenk} when a steam sale was rollin' into internet town. I tried the game. I had no expectations. I didn't read into the game info too much, I just dove in- and was shocked to find the game play choppy, wonky, and my keyboard/mouse skills just weren't up to par for this game. Make sure to check the game specs to see if you can play the game like it is meant to be played. Some will also say the game play is not very good. I think you really have to be a story-driven game player to get through this game while enjoying it. Sometimes the game play tends to be "drawn out" at times. Sometimes you don't know what you are suppose to be doing. But once you get the hang of what the game wants you to do, you will have a better time. 

Fast forward to 2018 {Now, Now? Yes sir Now.}
On a hp pavilion 500 series with an upgraded graphics card- smooth housework from there. With my handy dandy Xbox controller,  I instantly dove in to finish this story that I started in 2015. I was impressed with the deep story line of a country that is going through a civil revolution against a corrupt  president.  The tasks set forth were not overly complicated, lots of actions [paths] to choose. Great war sounds and effects. And I was able to complete 100% achievements for the game- Not broken.

Over all, a game not for everybody. But a good game for those who liked it. The story that I now have an ending for. If anyone wants any "much needed tips" before diving into the game, I have added to the Sunset community a Helpful Tips Guide. Check it out.
