author: {'steamid': '76561198013750945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1519591234}
review:
Full disclosure: I got this game for $4.50 through Humble Bundle. I liked it quite a bit, but I don't know that it's a $20 game, so grab it on sale if you can.

I have to admit, the first few hours of this game are a bit repetitive and slow. The first few journal entries seem to be mostly words for the sake of words, there are a lot of tasks that seem to be simply filler tasks, and I did nearly give up. 

However, if you're willing to play through that, about halfway through is where the game gets good. Decisions the player makes start having consequences to the world outside the apartment, and the story becomes FAR more engaging. Also, I have to say that the music and sense of humor in the game really added to the gameplay for me. Why simply clean up the toy soldiers, when I could arrange them into a neat pyramid? And the player builds, over time, a real attachment to the apartment, because you have a lot of control over how it looks, based on the decisions you make throughout the game. It really does start to seem like your home.

My biggest complaint (other than price) is the achievements. There's practically no variety... half of them are just "did you find this tiny book/record that was only there for one day?" It encourages exploration of the apartment every day, sure, but there could have been a LOT more variety, based off of the amount of choices you make throughout the game. I'd do away with about 50% the book finding achievements. As much as I like unlocking achievements, even I got tired of looking for books every single day. 

In the end, I just finished the game, and I'm left with the same feeling as when I finish a good book. Like I've been plopped back into real life again, and I feel almost homesick for the story I left behind. While I wouldn't give this game quite top marks, I would give it a solid 7/10, and recommend it if it's on a good sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165692237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1518919063}
review:
Największym problemem produkcji Tale of Tales jest fakt, że wszyscy (w tym producenci) nazywają je grami, kiedy nazywać ich należy inaczej. Nie wiem, instalacją artystyczną, interaktywnymi obrazami etc. Oczywiście, jak wszyscy wiemy, gry są dziełami sztuki. Niemniej, jak i z kinem, książkami, obrazami, dzieła sztuki mogą być, krótko mówiąc, czytadłami brukowymi, popcornowymi blockbusterami czy zwykłymi akwarelnymi malunkami krajobrazów sprzedawanymi pod zamkiem królewskim po pięć zeta. Niestety, kiedy mówimy o grach, zazwyczaj je z góry klasyfikuje się do tej "niższej" rozrywki, porównując do podanych przykładów. 

Rozumiem też, że nazywanie projektów ToT grami ma na celu pokazanie, że gry komputerowe to performance, to happening, to spektakl, to manifest. Ich produkcje krzyczą - jesteśmy grami, ale nie takimi jakie stereotypowo sobie prywołujecie jako gry, tylko interaktywnymi wystawami, jesteśmy grami i sztuką, jesteśmy! I mnie cieszy fakt, że coraz więcej osób, jak krytyków tak i graczy, sięga po takie gry, i docenia ich wartość artystyczną.

Niemniej, każdy performance i happening, mimo określonej nieprzewidywalności w procesie, jest maksymalnie "wylizany" - wszystko ma znaczenie, każde działanie jest zaplanowane na tyle, by w sposób komfortowy (bądź z zamiaru nie) przekazać myśl, którą chce przekazać. I to jest największy problem Sunset - technicznie jest w okropnym stanie. Jest w stanie wieszać się na najniższych opcjach graficznych, tryb 2,5D się rozpływa i traci jakąkolwiek perspektywę, i to w grze która jest bardzo prosta zarówno graficznie, jak i technicznie. Interakcja z obiektami jest utrudniona w ciul, zaś kiedy mamy opcję wyboru, aby móc wybrać pożądane przez nas działanie, musimy zająć się pixelhuntigiem (uwaga aktualna dla sposobu poruszania się za pomocą klawiatury, sterowania padem bądź tylko myszką nie próbowałem). Co zabawne, niektóre przedmioty (ważne!) są w stanie zwyczajnie się nie załadować. Albo obiekty tracą więź z fizyką, np. pudła zamiast stać oparte o ścianę opierają się o powietrze. Można by było to przeżyć, ale bohaterka też jest popsuta - nie zawsze się porusza kiedy potrzebujemy, nie zawsze wykonuje nasze polecenia.

Powyższe bardzo poważnie psuje odbiór danego dzieła, które łączy w sobie ogromną ilość elementów - mamy tutaj bardzo dobrze opisaną historię głównej bohaterki, która, wbrew swojej woli, jest wciągnięta w rewolucję (i historię samego powstania, które rozgrywa się za oknem). Jej narracja jest naturalna, kiedy czytamy jej dziennik i słuchamy jej monologów (czasami ocierających się o bycie manifestami) dotyczących bezsensu wojny w jakiej uczestniczy, utożsamiamy się z nią w całości. Tematy podejmowane przez bohaterkę nie ograniczają się jedynie wojną czy rewolucją - mamy też omówione problemy równouprawnienia rasowego i płciowego, problemy wojny, sztuki, miłości. Uniwersalne problemy, w mniejszym bądź większym stopniu dotyczące każdego nas.

Mimo ww. problemów technicznych, jesteśmy w stanie (choć z zacinkami) poczuć ten specyficzny klimat - jak nijak, za oknem toczy się wojna. Mimo że wiemy, że w mieszaniu naszej bohaterce nic nie zagrozi, kiedy wybucha dom obok podskakujemy w krześle. Kiedy za oknami odgrywa się istne piekło z bombardowaniem wieżowców i pałaców, po mieszkaniu zaczynamy się przemieszczać z niepokojem, z ostrożnością. Muzyka, rzadka i włączana przez nas samych, wpisuje się idealnie, i nie dziwię się, że soundtrack można zakupić dodatkowo (BTW - wow, Malukah brała udział w jego nagraniu).

I choć pierwotnie też narzekałem na to, że jesteśmy bardzo ograniczeni w czasie (na rozgranie jednej "godziny na dzień" mamy maksymalnie 30 realnych minut), szybko się do tego przyzwyczaiłem i zacząłem odbierać to jako ten niezbędny element happeningu w którym bierzemy udział.

Heppeningu, w którym musimy wziąć udział. Niezależnie od naszych poglądów i przekonań. Szczególnie w obecnych, niespokojnych czasach.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025848743', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1517766706}
review:
Only when I started playing, I noticed the mixed reviews. When purchasing it, I trusted a German game magazine which gave it a very good rating. The thing about Sunset is that it's caught in the middle ground between a game and art. I never played anything else from the now defunct publisher Tale of Tales and haven't heard of any other of their games before. Their approach was to create elegant and emotionally rich art for computers interactive entertainment.

Sunset is a good example for this approach and why it failed. You are a black housekeeper in the South American state of Anchuria. A totalitarian regime terrorizes the people. Your boss is a bigshot with a pivotal role in this system and the resistance against it. Your task is to do the daily chores. You can choose whether you want to do each task in a pleasing or a cold way. When the daily chores are done, there's time left to examine the appartment, write a diary or play some music. This is repeated for more than 40 days.

Altogether, I enjoyed the game. It's a unique approach to storytelling. I really felt involved in the story. I liked the style and especially the choice of music which is rather intellectual but excellent. I didn't mind that not much is happening. It's mostly a calm game, almost a walking simulator if it weren't in the same appartment all days. But I couldn't imagine ever playing this without Steam achievements. Finding those was a big part of my enjoyment. I doubt that I ever will play this again after getting the resolution. A game for mature slow gamers who like visual novels and don't mind quality of graphics and gameplay taking a backseat to story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033427899', 'num_games_owned': 961, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1507645012}
review: A gripping, beautiful game discussing politics, love, and war through the eyes of an African American woman hired as a maid in a fictional country amidst a civil war. As she explores the apartment, you control how involved she gets in the life of the wealthy man who the apartment belongs to and the country she is transplanted in. A very creative way of telling a story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045989928', 'num_games_owned': 772, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1615350695}
review: Great method of presenting a story. Enjoyed my time here

author: {'steamid': '76561198082286500', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1510787025}
review: This was pretty much one of the best adventure/exploration games i played in a long time. Smart, well written, emotionally investing, but a little clunky, and hard on the computer. Still, i want to play it again on a better system. Also, genuinely stylish. I need no more game elements than this, just give me an apartment to snoop around in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131701503', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1029, 'last_played': 1484998643}
review:
I tend to think of [b]Sunset[/b] as a case study in why cliches become cliches: they work.  [b]Sunset[/b] tries to be unique and original, but the unfortunate result is a mess.  Both the story and the gameplay are unengaging, leaving us with the worst of both worlds.

The story in [b]Sunset[/b] is about a military coup and the counter-revolution in a fictional Latin American country in the 70s.  That's an interesting setting.  But then the decision was made to tell the story from the point of view of an outsider who has only limited involvement in the plot.  What little Angela does occurs off-screen; all we see is the same apartment day after day, so most events are told rather than shown.  Then there's a romantic subplot between Angela and another character that we never see or talk to; I think even in-story, they never actually meet till the end.  This all serves to make the narrative feel distant and artificial.

The gameplay can be described as a first-person clean-em-up; each in-game day you have a list of tasks and a short period of time to do them in.  Perhaps not the most exciting possibility, but it could offer some amusement.  Except that there are no consequences for not doing the tasks.  What is particularly damning is that since you are paid to be a cleaner, there's actually an in-universe reason why failing would have a cost.  By ignoring it, both immersion and any sense of a challenge are lost.

It's a shame, as there are some original ideas here.  If there had been some reason to actually do the cleaning tasks, and your actions could have more of an effect on the direction of the story, this could have been enjoyable.  Not for everyone, but at least worthwhile.  As it is, I can't recommend [b]Sunset[/b].  Even if you like the atmospheric narrative/walking simulator genre, there are much better ones out there than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004545664', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1504014647}
review:
The game description does a good job of telling you what it is about, and other reviews as well, so I won't go into that. I'll just talk about why I liked the game.

Because I actually really like this game, and honestly have some trouble understanding some (most?) of the vitriol it has received.

The mechanics are extremely simple, and they serve well the way you get immersed in the story: through your own interpretations and actions. The immersion I mean here is not the one conveyed by narrative information - you get that quite directly and in a pretty linear way. No, the immersion really comes from the multiple possibilities you have to get involved with every detail of the game. Your choice of doing the chores in a certain way (or of not doing them at all), the interpretation of the paintings and the statues, the simple pleasure of looking at the gorgeous appartment... all this goes a long way, and as the game progresses you'll see your relation to these objects and choices be recalled.

Obviously, not everything is perfect: the character's walking animation is sometimes a bit weird (and in one occasion you can see the reflection of the back of your own head), the politics and philosophy are sometimes a bit simplified, and the relationship between the protagonist and the appartment owner can evolve in a bit of a contrived way, depending on your choices. But this all remains completely acceptable overall.

One point I absolutely have to praise the game for is the music: it is *really* good, quite varied, and goes very well with the whole ambience. Special points for the attention to detail in the sound design: wearing headphones in-game changes the stereo image of the music. Simple and completely brilliant idea.

So if you like exploring a nice appartment while History unfolds just beyond your reach but still affects you strongly, and if you like to take your time in a game, and if you like nice visuals and very nice music, Sunset is definitely for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152571270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1501500507}
review: Довольно хорошая игра с интересной историей. Если вы хотите хороший сюжет - то пожалуйста, но вот оптимизации нет и скорей всего не будет. У меня железо приличное, но при этом игра люто тормозит и лагает. Так что, если вы готовы пожертвовать удобством ради приятной философской драмы, то смело покупайте игру.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027973295', 'num_games_owned': 1826, 'num_reviews': 1850, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1654985836}
review:
Последняя на текущий момент игра Tale of Tales. И, похоже, что мы не увидим новых "шедевров" от этой студии. 

Sunset — это, наверное, самая дорогая игра разработчиков, качество деталей серьезно выросло в сравнении с предыдущими работами студии. Вложившись в эту игру, разработчики крупно провалились.

С релизом Sunset выяснилось, что игры студии с претензией на высокое искусство, в общем-то, никому не упали. Они интересны очень маленькой аудитории, исчисляемой буквально несколькими тысячами игроков.

Непонятно, на что надеялись Tale of Tales, но их новую игру купило так мало человек, сколько и в прошлый раз. Результат был немного очевиден, разработчики решили больше не заниматься производством коммерческих игр. Странно, что это не произошло еще в 2009 году.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025411932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1498790527}
review:
I'm glad I got this on discount. This game was frustrating.  Aside from creating horrible motion sickness if I played for more than 1 hour, the game treats you like garbage. 

More than once I found myself unable to complete an objective regardless of having done so on previous weeks simply because doors were closed or the items needed were not accessable. I can't decide if that was the entire point this game was trying to make at how utterly useless you are that you cannot 'set the table' using a table cloth found elsewhere in the flat.

I was genuinely interested in seeing this play through as a story, but the game mechanics were so distracting due to how unpredictable they were. Maybe I couldn't achieve all of these things unless I went back and did things differently on prior days, but there is no way I will ever try replaying this game to find out. 

I think this is one example of a game that would have done much better off as a novel. Maybe then I both would have felt more invested in following the story and spend less time worrying over missing out symbolism, accidentally following red herrings, or missing key details of the story,

author: {'steamid': '76561198141944565', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1498403185}
review:
Le jeu s'est fait descendre sur internet et sur steam, franchement c'est regrettable et triste en même temps vu que c'est en partie ce qui a fait fermer le studio. C'est d'ailleurs un gros souci des critiques sur les simulateurs de marche... Deux camps s'affrontent entre ceux qui disent " le Jeu Vidéo, ca doit être une Expérience, faire ressentir des Emotions, c'est de l'Art , tant pis si ca lag, si ça plante, ou si on paie cher pour 2 heures de jeu, si vous ne ressentez rien, vous êtes des moutons" et ceux qui disent "y'a rien à faire dans ce genre d'expérience, on se fait chier, on s'ennuie, c'est pas un jeu, on arrive pas à y trouver un sens c'est des jeux bobo intello casu d'auteur qui se la pètent, on préfère payer 20e de plus que cette expérience chelou et acheter le dernier AAA".

J'ai rarement vu de critique constructive qui m'a aidé à me faire un avis intéressant sur un simulateur de marche ou un indé de niche, mais j'ai pas regretté de l'avoir pris car, selon moi, il m'a touché et intéressé, et mérite qu'on y passe du temps.

Voila ce commentaire est vain et pas très utile, mais surtout un ptit soutien à Tale of Tales, et merci à Pseudoless de m'avoir conseillé ce jeu. Son analyse plus pertinente et développée ici : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C56MzkIJbRU

author: {'steamid': '76561198001060396', 'num_games_owned': 776, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1710617756}

очень интересный способ подачи сюжета

author: {'steamid': '76561198002252866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 526, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1498320603}
review:
[h1] ラテン・アメリカ版「家政婦は見た」 [/h1] 

軍事クーデターが発生した中米の小国で、ある大金持ちに雇われ、パートタイムのハウスキーパーとして働く主人公。

勤務時間である日没までの1時間の間にアイロンがけや掃除、洗濯などメモで指示された作業をこなしていく。
基本はコレの繰り返しだ。
自分以外の人間が、雇用主ですら登場しないというなんとも実験的なスタイルとなっている。
作中のストーリーは、すべて主人公のモノローグによって語られる形式だ。

とはいえ、ただそれだけでは済まないのが面白いところ。クーデターが首都での内戦に発展するにつれ、窓の外では砲爆撃の煙が上がり、なにやらきな臭い展開となっていく。
家政婦がうっかり見ちゃった雇用主の秘密や、次々と明かされている主人公の事情なんかも興味深い。

なんというか、家事シミュレーターのついているビジュアルノベルといった感じだろうか。「ゲーム」と呼ぶのは、あまり正確ではないかもしれない。
万人にはオススメしにくいが、個人的には2時間たっぷり楽しめた。

author: {'steamid': '76561197966123429', 'num_games_owned': 776, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1578774440}
review:
I'm a good fan of walking simulators when there is a good story to back it up. The context was pretty interesting, a subject and area that is not often spoken of in video games. You are a maid in charge of the house of a very important person and must do some cleaning and so everyday following the instructions of the owner that you'll never see in person. 

I got bored very quickly, there are so few things to do everyday and the game doesn't have a lot to say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145459010', 'num_games_owned': 1535, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1551648935}
review: เล่นเป็นแม่บ้าน(คนดำ)ทำตามภารกิจงานบ้านในแต่ละวันในคอนโดหรู ระบบแปลกดี ภาพสวย ไว้เล่นแก้เซ็ง

author: {'steamid': '76561197992985917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1494991555}
review: I really enjoyed Sunset - I think it suffered an unreasonable backlash. The fact that you play as a black female maid is an essential part of the character of the game, not simple trolling (but would that be so bad?) - yes, Sunset is political, but that's also part of the point. The game is encouraging you to put yourself in this woman's very specific shoes, and it's asking - what would you do in this situation? I think that's truly unusual among games, and even among "walking simulators". Although I should note that Sunset is more of a game than other games in this genre. You have time limits, you have goals. It's incontestibly a game, using game mechanics to encourage you to get in the head of a character. Sunset should be celebrated for pushing the envelope.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032429849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1473255141}
review:
[i][b]Sunset[/b][/i] n’évite ni les incohérences, ni quelques clichés et maladresses d’écriture, donnant parfois l’impression au joueur de ne pas contrôler la narration autant qu’il le voudrait. Au-delà des quelques défauts techniques, il demeure pourtant en tête des mois après la fin d’une première partie, et l’envie de retourner dans cet univers si lointain et si proche à la fois. Ce qu’il faut retenir de [i][b]Sunset[/b][/i] et qui en fait une réussite au-delà de sa direction artistique, c’est la façon dont [b]Tale of Tales[/b] traite généralement avec succès des thèmes difficiles à aborder et vous permet de bâtir une relation que vous aurez envie de construire et dans laquelle vous vous sentirez impliqué. Il y aura bien sûr un peu d’ennui et de lassitude, mais de ceux qui sont en cohérence totale avec ce qu’ils mettent en scène, à l’image de la répétitivité de [i]Papers, Please[/i]. Jouant sur les échelles, de l’individuel au collectif, humain et politique, [i][b]Sunset[/b][/i] remporte le pari d’être ambitieux et de tenir en grande partie ses promesses.

Lire la critique complète sur [url=http://kulturkonfitur.fr/sunset/]Kultur & Konfitur[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198056773079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1494714966}
review: I wanted to like this game, the art style was interesting and fit with an overall 70's theme, but after just under an hour I already found it a clunky pixel hunting slog-fest. Trying to figure out how to clean the windows is not my idea of a good time. I won't go as far as to say this is a bad game, I just never found it engaging...at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998785170', 'num_games_owned': 1759, 'num_reviews': 247, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1494541662}
review: The idea is sort of interesting, and I was kind of curious to see how it all played out, but I couldn't bring myself to finish it because the actual interaction with it gets kind of tedious, and it's kind of unpolished too. It's a shame it was such a flop though, because there aren't a lot of people who do the kind of stuff Tale of Tales did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177850115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1479244651}
review: It was good at first, but it becomes fairly repetitive. I found myself losing interest after the first few days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067280057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1515989841}
review:
This game quickly became one of m favorites as I played it for the fiers ttime. I understand why it may not have been everyone's cup of tea. The developers took several risks, not the lesat of which is choosing a protagonist with whom many gamers may not readily identify, and making hers the only character players see and hear from during the game. 

Then there is the setting of the game. While the story takes place in the capitol city of a country in the midst of a military coup, the game takes place in one apartment which, though in the city, seems far removed from the drama and danger of the fight between the military coup and the rebellion. The explosions and gunfire are seen and heard through the windows of the apartment. Only rarely does the external politcal struggle and guerilla warfar invade the aparment, and then the player, though the protagonist, onlly sees and experiences the aftermath. 


Iin fact, the two main characters -- the protagonist and the owner of hte penthouse she his hired to clean once a week, just for one hour before sunset -- aren't even major players in the political intrigue and warfare. Of the two, the protagonist is the farthest remoived from the action. Her involvement is limited to choices that influence of assist her employer and/or her brother -- who is a leader of the rebellion, and the other unseen and virtually unheard major player in the rebellion.

The developers set themselves up with several significant challenges, which forced them to make choices that would have the effect of severly limiting the games audiende, but managed to produce a compelling game that still haunts me after playing it through just once. Initially, the protagonist seems almost to enigmatic to engage players, but her voice grows stronger and her character clearer as the game progresses, influenced by the player's choices, much as the story line itself. 

The developers risked the game being monotonous by essentially limiting the story to once character's view and voice, and then only in one place. 

Gameplay is essentially a series of apartment visits, punctuated by tasks that are by their nature mundane, even when they influence the direction of the story. The only changes are the external state of the city and the fighting, and the internal state of the relationship between the protagonist and her employer. Those changes are reflected in changes to the apartment that are mostly subtle from one visit to the next, and only become more dramatic as the story draws to its end. While its ending drags a bit (at least the one ending I played), the story is made no less compelling for all its subtlety. 

Perhaps this games fails to satisfy some because it straddles the line between classic game and interactive fiction. The apparent focus on the latter may have led to game mechanics that frustrated some players The developers certainly took a risks that would limit its appeal. But where Sunset succesdes it does so preciselly because of those risks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1487794684}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Sunset is a game developed and published by Tale of Tales

I really wish I could praise this game but the premise seemed very interesting, and the story has a lot going for it in terms of premise but in terms of execution, it falls flat

The game itself is extremely repetitive and dull and the presentation of the plot falls flat. I went into this expecting story, but the presentation and lack of exploration and/or gameplay really sank it for me

The idea of your actions affecting the storyline is interesting, and that concept does present some interesting persistent elements in the game, but overall it ends up feeling like an unfinished or poorly-executed mechanic

I think the concept is excellent and the plot is intriguing, but there's not enough going in terms of gameplay and overall execution, think twice before purchasing Sunset...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198017392185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1465030984}
review:
"The Path" van Tale of Tales was een interessant, zei het verre van volmaakt spel. Daarom had ik best hoge verwachtingen van Sunset. De trailer en screenshot zien er mooi uit en in concept is het een interessant spel. Jammer genoeg hebben veel reviewers gelijk, het tempo ligt stomweg te laag. En dan doel ik op zowel het tempo waarmee je door het huis loopt als het tempo waarin het verhaal zich ontvouwt. En hoewel ik een redelijk vlotte pc (i5 met 16 gb geheugen) en grafische kaart (GTX 980) heb, duikt de framerate regelmatig onder de 20 fps. Wat onbegrijpelijk is voor een spel dat zich afspeelt in een kleine ruimte, met weinig beweging. De besturing voelt houterig aan en het menu is een rommeltje, navigeren gaat moeizaam en sommige opties zijn niet toegelicht, zodat je niet weet welk effect het zal hebben.
De twee uur die ik het spel gespeeld heb, voelen als zeker vier keer zo veel, omdat er zo weinig gebeurt van dag tot dag. Het appartement verandert telkens een beetje en de ruimtes die beschikbaar zijn wijzige ook. Als je per dag meer tijd zou hebben om activiteiten uit te voeren, er meer ruimtes en activiteiten beschikbaar waren, zou het waarschijnlijk minder hebben tegengevallen. Nu ben ik toch bang dat ik het spel minstens twee keer zal moeten doorspelen om alle achievements te behalen en alles te zien wat het spel te bieden heeft. Maar ik vrees dat de verschillende keuzes die je kunt maken slechts een marginale verschil zullen maken. 
Ik kan het spel dan ook niet aanbevelen, zelfs niet in de uitverkoop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970451270', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1468220012}
review:
I really wish I could recommend this game - the premise seemed very interesting, and the story has a lot going for it in terms of premise.

But in terms of execution, it falls flat. The game itself is repetitive and dull and the presentation of the plot falls flat. I went into this expecting story, but the presentation and lack of exploration and/or gameplay really sank it for me.

The idea of your actions affecting the storyline is interesting, and that concept does present some interesting persistent elements in the game, but overall it ends up feeling like an unfinished or poorly-executed mechanic (e.g. turning lights on to make the apartment feel more inviting ends up being a very boring farming-type process).

I think the concept is excellent and the plot is intriguing, but there's not enough going in terms of gameplay and overall execution to make it worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029191416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1485887877}
review:
Sunset, un videojuego con una ambientación y premisa atractiva pero tremendamente devastada por su pésimo apartado técnico. A Sunset le ocurre lo peor que le podría pasar a un walking simulator: que no te permita caminar. Compré este juego gracias a una recomendación y no ha podido ser una decepción mayor. 

Aunque su historia puede ser interesante, los pensamientos tan simplones y aleatorios de la protagonista aderezados con la mala redacción de estos y su cuestionable ortografía de la que han hecho gala (supongo que esto tiene que ver con la traducción y quizás no están tan mal escritos en la versión original) no ayuda en absoluto a integrarte en la trama, una trama que además, se ve lastrada por una mecánica de juego torpe y repetitiva que se basará en completar una serie de tareas al día que no evitarán que bosteces a lo Snorlax mucho más de lo que te gustaría. Un diseño de escenarios con proporciones dignas de una casa de Pin y Pon. Te sentirás como un gigante, sobre todo en la cocina donde la encimera te llega prácticamente por las rodillas. Una iluminacion que te quemará las pestañas o te dejará ciego si te ves obligado a bajar el brillo por la luz tan intensa que desprende una lavadora que muy probablemente estuvo en algún lugar del espacio exterior. Una terrible optimización con unos requisitos escandalosamente exigentes (4GB RAM mínimo / 16GB RAM recomendado) que ni siquiera tienen una justificación razonable, con unas texturas muy pobres, sin apenas animaciones y un frame rate más que deficiente. Tu PC y tu mente pedirán clemencia tras un tiempo de juego y tu cartera llorará muy fuerte tras pagar su inmerecido precio. 

No me gusta hacer "hater review". Toda obra lleva su trabajo y esfuerzo y no soy quien para "tirarlo abajo" de una forma cruel y más aún si eres un estudio independiente. Pero que seas indie no quiere decir que te lo pueda perdonar todo. Si no puedes hacer BIEN un juego en 3D en primera persona porque tus recursos no te lo permiten y es un proyecto muy ambicioso para ti, ¡no lo hagas! 

En fin, me había propuesto ser más personal en mis análisis de Steam y aquí lo tenéis. Simplemente, no puedo recomendarlo. Obviamente, no soy nadie para decir si compras o no este videojuego, pero pagar su precio completo es un auténtico reto. Si lo haces y encima lo disfrutas, te habrás convertido en mi nuevo héroe/heroína.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042228090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1443826961}
review: An interesting method of story exploration, Sunset gives you bits and pieces of its story as you perform tasks in someone's home as a housekeeper. The story itself isn't groundbreaking, but the fresh presentation is worth trying. A well-made, charming game, Sunset definitely takes its time and isn't for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152240484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 307, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1484378839}
review:
가정부가 되어 집안일을 도맡아 하는 게임 .
주인과는 대부분 쪽지로만 소통을 하고있어서
대면할수있는 다른 인물은 없다.
플레이하다보면 주인공이 주저리 주저리 독백을 하는데
잘 들어보면 게임의 맛이 배가되니 집중해서 듣는게 좋다.
근데 굳이 스토리를 모르더라도 
인테리어가 참한 펜트하우스에
약간 과장된 노랑빛의 석양이 드리워진 풍경을
감상하고있노라면 뭔가 힐링되는 느낌이 든다.
내용물에 비해 가격이 비싼건 사실이지만
풍경 감상하는걸 좋아한다면 구매해볼만한 게임이다.

7 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198013115835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1459631096}
review:
Sunset is difficult to describe. It's about many things, but none of them are in your face.

You play as a housekeeper of a man you've never met face to face, and can choose whether to do your chores with warmth or coldness - if you choose to do them at all. Not taking action is just as valid as diligently going through your daily list of tasks. The man who hired you is an art collector, in a world where art is both losing its value and valuable enough to be saved in his private penthouse. You are an engineer whose life forced her to become a housekeeper. Along the way you will learn about the political situation in the new country you'd just moved to, write thoughts in your diary, and make a little space for yourself in a stranger's home.

The biggest downside is that it can feel a bit 'heavy' to run because of the game engine and may require a restart after several hours of gameplay. I played it on a laptop, so take this with a grain of salt.

Sunset is absolutely worth playing and if there's one thing I can tell you, it is that I've never found a review that I agreed completely with, because the story can be seen so differently based on your own personal experiences. It's multi-faceted and more of a meditative experience, rather than a game to blast through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011189510', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1440413457}
review: Pelaaja pääsee seuraamaan vallankumousta Angela Burnes nimisen kodinhoitajan silmin. Kerran viikossa pelaaja käy siivoamassa Ortegan luksusasuntoa. Askareiden ohella mm. keräät vinyylilevyjä, lehtileikkeitä tai käyt dialogia isännän jättämien muistilappujen kautta. Sunsetissä ei alleviivata valintojen merkitystä, joten pelaaja ei aina tiedä, milloin hän on vaikuttanut maailmaan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009485811', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1497290389}

author: {'steamid': '76561198071767827', 'num_games_owned': 1130, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1435990192}
review:
Sunset presents itself as a narrative-based experimental videogame, an experience constructed from its character, exploration, interaction and time management.

It's neither of those things.

The narrative, which reads like Cold War fan fiction written by someone who skimmed through a Che Guevara biography once, runs along the game almost unconnected of the actual gameplay or your actions. The themes and conflicts are unsubtly spelled out for you, in what feels less like fiction and more like low-tier political propaganda. The dissonance between the "importance" of the plot and the little influence you have as a character is never resolved, all wrapped up by a pretentious, cliched non-ending for a story that never went anywhere or said anything as important as the game takes itself to be.

The main protagonist seems less like a character and more like a megaphone for the developers to spout their views from, having little to no agency in the plot besides pointless busywork, which the developers would like you to think are important choices. A ridiculous concept considering there's a literal war happening outside the walls of the room you're locked in. The themes are constructed with zero respect for the historical context of the events, culture, symbols and conflicts referenced, with no nuances or decision given to the player of what to think or interpret. It's narrative hand-holding pretending to be educational.

The gameplay itself, which scraps the bottom of what could be considered a videogame to begin with, is an example of what Tale of Tales considers to be "experimental game design": that is, to remove those essential elements from which videogames are constructed, rather than reconsider or expand on them, leaving a game that seems built as the equivalent of removing the wheels and motor of a car and pretending this is "an advancement in automobile technology."

It runs horribly in most computers, and seems completely buggy: the first time I ran it, the 'activities' didn't load into the game's engine, leaving a barren level with nothing in there to do, making me think that I was actually playing the game wrong. An hour later, I realized that it was the game being shoddily made. The solution to the bug? Run the game again and hope that it works the next time. And that's on top of the ridiculously bad performance and cheap "Photoshop for Dummies" GUI.

And even when I could "play the game", I discovered that the game's 'activities' were nothing but button prompts, followed by title cards informing me that I had done the activity, which puts this game below the definition of an actual simulator, into what can only be considered to be a text adventure with a low-effort level rendered on top. THIS GAME IS JUST NOT FUN. There's no progression, nothing to learn, no skills to apply, no puzzles to solve, and even ignoring the gameplay, it's also not fun on a narrative level. There's just nothing compelling going on here.

So, considering the game's text is incompetent, the gameplay cheap and pointless, and that the title might not even work when you run it, I think Sunset can only be regarded as trash not worth any asking price, and an insult to the craft of videogame making AND gaming audiences everywhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006684379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1478379499}
review: The colour palette and sound design of this game is awe inspiring. Combined with carefully placed pieces of history, both real and imagined, this game creates a sense of nostalgia for simpler times mixed with forebording for the complexity of life. I recommend it for anyone looking for a simulation style game focused on aesthetic and analytical introspection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194459855', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1465511686}
review:
So many negative reviews for this game. What a shame.

Yes, it's a walking simulator. But there's a lot more to it. What I enjoyed the most was that it really made me walk in someone else's shoes and think about problems that I personaly don't face IRL.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042838346', 'num_games_owned': 5512, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1477329250}
review:
[i]Alors soyons clairs, j'ai toujours eu un faible pour les jeux de Tale of Tales car ils ont le don de sortir des sentiers battus. Souvent réussis à mon sens, ils laissent aussi le joueur perplexe. L'expérience est si inédite qu'on en revient à la question : "est-ce un bon jeu ?". La réponse est assez difficile à obtenir. Eh oui, parle-t-on du jeu dans son sens commun, en tant qu'amusement ou du jeu dans un sens plus large qui ferait du médium vidéoludique un moyen de transmettre une idée, une émotion sans pour autant qu'on s'amuse réellement à l'obtenir ? J'ai été bien désolée de voir le studio fermer ses portes après la sortie de Sunset, un titre qui a clairement divisé les joueurs de par son originalité. Alors, trop original pour des joueurs habitués à un certain format de "jeu" ?[/i] 

Le scénario interpelle de prime abord. Incarner une femme de ménage, on a vu plus palpitant ! Et si au final tout le charme du jeu résidait dans le fait que l'on va suivre le train de vie d'une jeune femme, qu'on va apprendre à la connaitre et qu'on va développer des routines comme on l'aurait fait nous-même, à sa place, dans la vie réelle ? C'est un peu déconcertant. On se dit "mais, est-ce qu'il va se passer quelque chose ?!" ; "est-ce qu'il y a un moment où on va faire autre chose que des tâches ménagères ?!" alors qu'en fait non, on ne va pas faire des trucs de ouf, on va juste vivre la vie d'une femme normale qui tente de survivre à la guerre qui a éclaté dans son pays. On laisse de côté les combats et les gunfights. Pour une fois on va vivre la tragédie sous un autre angle. En ce sens le jeu est assez poignant, voire déprimant à certains moments. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=786582359 Les réflexions que va faire la protagoniste interpellent qui veut bien se plonger dans l'histoire. Outre des thèmes tels que le caractère éphémère de la vie ou la vanité de la guerre on va aussi aborder une réflexion sur la postérité et l'art comme un leg pour nos enfants, comme quelque chose qui va attester de nos existences. La narration est profonde et riche, c'est ce qui fait la force de Sunset.

En revanche, côté gameplay le jeu reste trop peu conventionnel pour être apprécié par les masses. Le jeu se déroule sur plusieurs mois et chaque semaine vous avez une heure de ménage à effectuer dans le loft d'un riche collectionneur d'art. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=786582402 Chaque action prend du temps : déambuler et observer les lieux fait passer le temps lentement, réaliser les tâches ménagères demandées va "consommer" de précieuses minutes et écrire le journal va, là encore, prendre beaucoup de temps. Pourtant la phase journal est très importante pour ne pas passer à côté de la narration, point fort du jeu je le rappelle. Après quelques jours une routine s'installe : on visite les lieux en regardant les livres ou nouveaux objets qui trainent par-ci par-là, on écrit son journal et on fait le travail demandé en dernier si le temps le permet. Vous ne serez pas récompensé pour les tâches effectuées ni puni si vous ne vous acquittez pas de votre travail cependant, bien que l'on peut voir cela comme une erreur de game design, il faut se prêter au jeu pour entrer dans le personnage. Aussi, certaines actions pourront se faire de façon neutre ou de façon à créer et entretenir une relation de plus en plus intime avec le mystérieux habitant des lieux. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=779511435 Ces choix vont changer la manière dont les deux êtres vont communiquer (par petits mots collés sur les murs ou posés sur les tables, la rencontre ne se fera pas de manière directe) mais leur impact ne sera pas déterminant sur le déroulement des événements. 

On pourra reprocher au jeu le sentiment de rush désagréable qu'il pourra nous procurer lors de certaines journées où le travail sera plus conséquent que d'autres et où l'on devra choisir entre réaliser une tâche ou écrire son journal. Pour un jeu narratif il est dommage d'avoir mis de telles barrières même si c'est par souci de réalisme qu'un tel choix a été fait. Et pourtant il y aura des journées où l'on va tourner en rond pour au final partir avant la fin du temps imparti. Ce déséquilibre des journées va de ce fait entacher l'expérience car il nous empêchera par exemple d'écouter le disque qu'on avait vu posé sur la table du salon, d'observer le livre que lisait l'homme et qu'il a laissé près de son lit ou de regarder par la fenêtre et de voir les dernières nouvelles sur l'avancée des rebelles qui défilent sur un panneau digital..etc.

Oui, vous risquez de vous ennuyer un peu par moments avec Sunset. Le rythme est lent, les journées sont nombreuses, l'appartement n'évolue que très peu passé les premiers jours où l'homme emménage dans les lieux. L'accent n’étant pas mis sur le challenge, votre seul but sera de suivre une histoire comme on regarderait un feuilleton, en collectant le plus d'informations possibles pour enrichir la narration. Encore une fois Sunset ne plaira pas à tout le monde mais il a le mérite de proposer quelque chose de nouveau et de le faire avec beaucoup de poésie.

[quote]Lisez d'autres avis sur ma page de curation : [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9002662/]Kitsune's Guide[/url][/b][/quote]

review: Al principio la idea es interesante y no parece lucir bien, pero a menos que hayan actualizado el juego, llega a tener problemas visuales. Aparte, es demasiado vacío. No se disfruta como otros juegos de su género.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975895891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 425, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1474712066}
review:
Ich wollte Sunset mögen, aber der Funke ist leider nie übergesprungen. Die Erzählung wäre an sich okay, selbst wenn sie nie überraschend ist oder einen nicht emotional abholen kann. Das Gameplay wird dem ganzen eher zur Last und es wäre gut gewesen noch viel mehr Erzähltexte bzw. Voice-Overs einzubauen.
Wurde auch mittendrin leider etwas unglaubwürdig und schien mir zu sehr zurechtgedichtet um weiterhin dieses Gameplay beizubehalten. Wäre nicht nötig gewesen, da das Gameplay sowieso keinen Spaß macht und auch mehr stört. Man hätte das spätestens in der Mitte auflösen müssen.

Für 5€ fänd ichs ganz okay. Für zwanzig Euro muss man schon echt abgehärtet sein und viel Monotonie und Repetives überstehen um die ganzen Achievements zu sammeln. Ich habe nur noch das Nötigste gemacht als ich gemerkt habe, dass da nichts mehr kommt.  

Das Spiel hat an sich ne gute Idee, aber es bleibt leider bloß beim guten Ansatz und schafft es nicht einen besonderen Moment zu kreieren.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046787531', 'num_games_owned': 712, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1456884817}
review:
This game has lots of very interesting and unique ideas that completely fail to come together. 

I love the idea of a Gone Home-style game where you learn about a character's personality through their living space, and making the protaganist a housekeeper provides a great justification for this and adds the potential for a bit more gameplay that what walking simulators normally have. The idea of watching a major revolution as a complete outsider who wants nothing to do with either side is also very interesting. 
Unfortunately, this game plays and runs terribly and fails to deliver a great story. Every day you have one "hour" to clean Ortega's apartment and do whatever tasks he has set out for you. You can do most tasks in two different ways, and choosing one will influence your relationship with Ortega. Instead of letting you choose between the two items on the same screen, you can only see one option at a time and will often have to awkwardly walk around whatever object you're trying to interact with to find the correct angle to trigger whichever option you want. When you do manage to succesfully interact with something, you are rewarded by the screen fading out and a seemingly somewhat arbitrary amount of in-game time passing. This process gets boring quickly, especially in later days when Ortega gives you fewer new tasks. It's also important to note that the game runs inexcuseably badly even though it has very simplistic (albeit pretty) graphics.
I also did not get invested in the characters and larger plot of the game. One of the biggest issues is that you are supposed to learn about your character through her journaling, but journaling is only triggered when you sit down, and then you have to watch her journal painfully slowly as that day's hour slips away. It's frequently literally impossible to complete all the day's tasks and also get the full journal entry. Your interactions with Ortega often feel very flat and limited and you are never really given much of a reason to care about the revolution.

This game takes lot of fantastic ideas and handles them all terribly. It's very disappointing and incredibly overpriced.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998266429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1468764456}
review:
+ The music and voice acting easily the best thing about this game, love the ability to play records.

- Unfortunately everything else just meanders a bit too long. 'Choice' games really need to feel you are following a story of a character you care about. It's very diffcult to find an emotional connection with the protaganist here. 

- Neutrality is not an option here, and the game definitely encourages you to join/help the revolution and also have a relationshp with Mr Ortega.

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030891319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1519035455}
review:
A really immersive, touching and atmospheric little game. The gameplay is all about subtelty and exploring the environment, very much "show not tell" for a lot of the narrative. Of course, if that's not your thing, you won't like it; maybe that's why there are so many (undeserved, in my opinion) negative reviews?
The game starts deceptively simple - you make your way to a high-ranking official's flat every afternoon, and have to complete a to-do list around house chores. Thing is, after a few days, you start noticing that you can complete the tasks in a couple of different ways every time, and that by exploring and looking at the right things you can start building a slow relationship with the flat owner. Your choices *will* affect the game, sometimes in unpredictable ways, and it's fascinating to see the characters develop through the choices they make. The story is also highly personal and although the every day actions are pretty trivial, there's a real sense of sadness, anger or even danger at various key points. That was a really nice surprise.
Graphics-wise the game has a very 1970s feel and palette obviously, again maybe not to everyone's taste (I personally really hate everything 70s!), but really well designed and elegant. It also makes a lot of cultural references to 20th century art/literature/music, which is quite interesting. 
It ran perfectly on my 2yo mid-range gaming PC, so no issues there. Controls were very simple, could have done with a little more explanation (for the alternate choices for example), but definitely not a deal-breaker.

Tl;dr: try it, and like me you may get a really nice surprise. :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997469880', 'num_games_owned': 2501, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1558916246}
review:
Another pretentious walking simulator? Yes! This is one I liked.

I couldn't tell you exactly why - maybe it was the unique experience of being a black maid cleaning some rich guy's place during a revolution - but I found it oddly compelling, at least enough to want to see the story through to the end.

The artwork was certainly different, and the apartment design was very mod-70s. I guess that appealed to me too - you don't see that sort of thing very often. The serious pretentiousness in the story (and everything that surrounds it) is sky high. Not sure why it clicked with me, but it did.

Without a doubt, this game will be an acquired taste. Performance is not great - luckily it doesn't need to be. That said, I was playing on an i7 4790 4GHz with an Nvidia GT 960, so...weaker rigs could conceivably find it unbearable - dunno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080464569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1463692263}
review: I really appreciate what they were trying to do, but I just got sick of cleaning someone else's flat in my free time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998056243', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 430, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1476436099}
review:
This game is one of the worst walking simulator I played. The 'walking simulator' genre is one of my favourite (actually maybe my favourite) and I play most of them. I had heard from some friends that this game was no masterpiece, but when I saw it in a bundle for 1$ I decided I would take the risk.

Well, the game first of all runs horribly. Given that the graphics are far from beautiful, the performance has no reason to be this low.
Other than that, the game mechanics are quite boring. In a 'walking simulator' the atmosphere is what counts, you have to be involved somehow in the story, in the environment. It is a 'walking simulator' (not meant negatively, for lack of a better word) so there is no action, there is nothing to shoot at, and of course if you don't deliver a thick atmosphere and great voice acting or good lore, you are not offering much to the players.
The 'plot' is barely there and the whole apartment / city / civil war thing, which could have been a great basis for a good involvement in the atmosphere/environment doesn't deliver. You don't feel it, and the little lore you can get about the protagonist's life by sitting on a chair and letting her writing her diary is naive, simplistic.

Honestly I didn't find anything good in the game. The house (apartment?) itself is very badly designed, the proportions are weird, of course it's meant to be a big modernist expensive house with lots of big rooms, but the result is that it looks incredibly empty and out of proportions compared to the character. If you do more or less everything, the game will last around 5 or 6 hours. If you can resist that long and don't get bored after the first hour. Definitely in my worst 5 in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969551714', 'num_games_owned': 1546, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1464464101}
review: Sunset has a beautiful aesthetic which makes you feel like you really are in the 70's. The game starts off simple, but don't let that fool you; the game's story is deep and emotional. The game took longer to finish than I expected, but it was worth every minute I spent on it. By the end you'll really feel at home in that apartment. Don't play/buy this game if you expect action. This game is a beautiful story of two people who fall in love despite never meeting face to face. Or not, because you can make decisions that influence the story. It's worth it playing this game at least twice to see all the differences in the story. I heartily recommend Sunset if you like more than just shooters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031340644', 'num_games_owned': 1415, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1464182374}
review: Sunset - единственная игра Tale of Tales, в глубине которой непозволительно сильно ощущается дно. Главное, что обязательно нужно знать неподготовленному игроку - вы будете убираться в одной и той же квартире три часа. В уборке сюжет. Как бы это странным не казалось, мы играем за уборщицу революционера выдуманного южного государства. И эта идея сама по себе интересна. Прибираясь в двухэтажном пентхаусе, мы находим шифры, оставленные (специально?) документы и разного рода литературу, за которую дают ачивки. Со временем, мы замечаем симпатию к революционеру со стороны уборщицы. Хозяин начинает оставлять записки, на которые можно отвечать. Как и с уборкой, всегда есть два стула. Можно ответить вопросительно или утвердительно. Сжечь газеты, или сжечь газеты с флагом революции. По окончании игры могу сказать, что смысла это оказывает никакого, но чисто психологически порой крайне некомфортно. И это единственный плюс игры. Работает такой подход внутри себя самого, но довольно быстро становится понятно, что игра... пустая? Да, именно так. Всё действие разворачивается в вашей голове, а самой игре мало что есть предложить помимо этого. Однообразный геймплей и плохая оптимизация - вот, что представляет собой Sunset, как игра, как независимый проект. И проблема очевидна. Раньше Tale of Tales не делали конкретно игры. Был некий концепт, обрастающий необычными механиками. Заявляя свой проект, как игру, ребята просчитались. Sunset - это концепт, обросший обычными, плохо реализованными однообразными механиками. Как уникальный experience - да, стоит попробовать. Как игра - забудьте, вам не сюда.

review:
"Back in college we had heated debates about the merits of depicting nudes in art.
Some saw it as another form of exploitation, and those discussions invariably centered around the objectification of women."
...
"But somehow the missing pieces render it more sensual. Without shame, it draws attention to its center.
My eyes trace the lines again, down the chest to the tender genitals."
...
"At least that statuette is beautiful, as opposed to what people do with gold nowadays:
Melt it down into bricks and hide those away in vaults, where no one can see them. [...]
Makes you wonder what the point is."
...
"Racial equality still seems like an unachievable utopian mirage in the States."
...
"It wasn't enough to steal African bodies.
They had to leech away the spiritual and aesthetic ideas too."
...
"I wonder if Gabriel Ortega prefers men. [...]
I mean, the apartment has all these statues of men, naked and gorgeous."
...
"Do we secretly hate art because we know it's going to survive us?"
...
"Every battle, every unfair trial, every lynching, every räpe, all lead to my existence."

author: {'steamid': '76561198057190823', 'num_games_owned': 1234, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1463861963}
review:
Perfecto, se me ha hecho un poco largo a pesar de las 4h de duración, mejorable la trama, pero una delicia que considero al nivel de firewatch. 

Totalmente rejugable ya que al parecer hay dos finales y me gustaría ver como terminaría el juego de no haber tomado ciertas acciones. Muy poético, y una banda sonora estupenda, aunque alguno de los días (fases) se añora algún vinilo que poner para tener de fondo musical, porque cuando la protagonista se pone a escribir en el diario, sin música, puede hacerse tedioso. 

De todos modos, muy muy recomendable, y ahora a muy buen precio con la rebaja :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197999217003', 'num_games_owned': 2570, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1463896969}
review:
[h1]THIS GAME SCORES [*0* | 1 | 2] = ~17% (0%-33%)[/h1]

Since I couldn't really play it, I can't say if it would be 1of4 or 2of4, so I'll just give it a 1of3.

Got this at 90% off (->2€) but still refunded it. Reason: Broken interface. (Most of the 31 minutes game time were spent changing options and contacting the devs via their website.)

Maybe (or maybe not) Sunset is a great creation on some level, but the devs failed the interface [i]too damn hard[/i] for me to ever find out. Therefore, I rather don't force myself through this and choose to "send them a message".



[h1]BROKEN MOUSE CONTROL[/h1]

Mouse speed depends on frame rate (so, even depends on where you look). If you look up and pull the mouse down quickly, you end up looking straight ahead, but if you do it slowly, you end up at the bottom, so this is absolutely not a mouse acceleration issue. (Even if so, whose fault would that be.)

Something is just really really broken with the mouse controls. The horz/vert mouse speed options are effective, but the speed is much too inconsistent, so it's not remotely a working fix.

Another problem: In the optional very cool 2.5D mode which prevents converging vertical lines (Photographers know what I mean.) which I would really like to use, the vertical mouse speed is always at max while you stand still, but is at whatever you set it to while you walk around. Bro-ken!

The game otherwise looks very good, has FOV slider with wide range, etc. - one would think that all is well, but the mouse control is [i]primary[/i], it's what connects me to (or keeps me away from) a 3D 1st person game world, and it's just [i]to damn broken[/i] in this case.

That's why I suggest to stay the hell away from this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031530121', 'num_games_owned': 1749, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1463879169}
review: For a dollar (at the Humble Store) I got to play as Foxxy Cleopatra while cleaning up and decorating some dudes penthouse suite.  I think she secretly wet her pants in his bed each day.  I might become a maid and interior decorator in real life now.  Oh, and I got to grease his telescope.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078794652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1459, 'last_played': 1456922238}
review:
Beautiful story, in a setting and with characters that we don't normally get to see in games. I really loved how gently the narrative reveals itself and how intricately the relationship between the characters develops. 

The story, setting and characters in this game have stayed with me long after finishing it. I'd recommend it to everyone who likes these story driven impactful narratives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138200962', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 923, 'last_played': 1672913397}
review:
Sunset has a few gameplay issues (yes, sometimes Angela doesn't always go exactly where you want her to, yes, there's very little indication of what you're supposed to do at the beginning...there's probably a lot of nitpicking to do) but it makes a perfect use of the music, the -thoroughly researched- aesthetic and the general atmosphere of 70's Latin America to create a lasting experience. 
I don't believe this game has a message (it lets us peek into Angela's mind, who has a lot of opinions, as a well-rounded character should, but doesn't try to force them on the player) but rather that it tries to create a place for the player to reflect - on war, art, love. The strength of the narrative is not the journal excerpts, as interesting as they might be; it is the fact that every detail of the gameplay and the surroundings has been designed to help carry it forward. In that sense, it is much more of a "real game" than those who have to beat you over the head with what they're trying to say.
It's certainly possible to be unmoved by Sunset - it is a peculiar game. Personally speaking, I think the strongest game experience I ever had was watching San Bavon slowly burning because of me while letting a requiem fill the air of the penthouse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114002903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1461124026}
review:
Sunset is a beautiful game that I can only accurately describe as unique and singular in its experience. It has its issues, but it's a good game, especially on sale. Keep in mind, it's basically a walking simulator, so it isn't for everyone. 
Essentially, you play a young woman who is hired to clean a man's apartment for one hour each week while he is not there. You have a list each day of what chores to do, which you can choose to fulfill or not. You can also explore the space, examining objects, playing records, unlocking diary entries, and doing other tasks that can affect how the story unfolds. As each day progresses, you are engrossed in a story about the corrupt government of Anchuria and the struggle of the rebel forces to overthrow it. Strangely enough, your choices will influence your involvement with the rebels and decide how the story plays out (supposedly - I've only played through it once, so I haven't tested other choices).

PROs:
+ voice acting: Angela has a warm voice that can add such depth to the simplest of dialog. Great talent here.
+ visual style: the retro colors and modern architecture make the space very surreal
+ story: a young woman's role in possibly overthrowing the government of a wartorn country, all determined by what she does for her faceless employer? Sounds weird, but I'm into it.
+ achievements: you can get a number of achivements in how you approach the relationship with Gabriel and what tasks you do (or don't do) around the house
+ atmosphere: sounds and visuals go very well together, as well as optional information you can find by examining book covers, sitting in the covered chair to access diary entries, etc. Playing records while explosions rock the city is also oddly charming.
+ drama: the events unfolding around you and the surrounding city makes for a tense, exciting atmosphere despite your confines to the apartment

CONs:
- performance: I have a gaming laptop and there were still framerate issues on lower quality settings, which was somewhat frustrating.
- clarity: the tasks you are given for each day are sometimes vague to the point it's unclear how to carry them out. (ie. "organize papers". What papers and in which room?) You'll likely waste a good amount of time trying to find out how to do the tasks rather than exploring.
- shallow decisions: while you do get to choose how you do your chores, as well as what all you do, the results seem to be very subtle, which isn't necessarily a good thing.
- gameplay mechanics: having only an in-game hour to accomplish everything AND explore is near impossible at times, especially when faced with the confusion of how to do everything on the task list. Navigation is also a pain, as I kept having to find my way around invisible barriers that made moving around a real nuisance.
- price: with the technical issues present, I wouldn't say this game warrants more than $10, maybe $15.

All in all, it's up to you whether you get this game or not. I got it on sale for $5 on the Humble Bundle store, and I enjoy it thoroughly. It has its shortcomings, but if you want a unique experience, this would be a good game to get on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138967991', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1520113293}
review:
[i]Sunset[/i] is a game that will either bore you, or move you deeply. Personally, it has become one of my favourite games, thanks to the subtlety and beauty it displays. 

[i]Sunset[/i] encapsulates one year of the life of Angela Burnes, an educated and ingenious African-American woman who emigrated from the US to the imaginary South American country of Anchuria in hopes of finding another, different if not better, life, and got trapped in a civil war. She now has has to work as a housekeeper in the apartment of Gabriel Ortega, a rich citizen and lover of the arts. For the player, this translates as having to accomplish some mundane tasks, such as dusting statues or setting the table for dinner. However, it is barely the focus of the game, which is based upon a narrative that can be accessed through Angela's thoughts (namely the diary she keeps, her reflexions in the elevator and her remarks when she interacts with some objects in the apartment).

Coming to know, little by little, who our protagonist is, what her thoughts are, is a beautiful experience, and it can be magnified by the relationship the player chooses to make her have with Ortega: while some may argue that a romantic relationship issuing from written notes between two people who never meet each other is a stretch, I reckon the game makes it work. And if the player doesn't want to go in that direction, a more neutral, friendship-based approach is possible. The political intrigue also adds a layer of oppression in the atmosphere of the game and plays an important part in understanding Angela's story. As the action is set in a context of civil war, violence always lingers in the background, visible to us only through the pillars of smoke that can be seen from the windows and the oppressive whirring of helicopters.

The art itself is absolutely gorgeous. While Angela's gestures can be a little contorted, the apartment itself is a joy to the eyes, and art lovers can entertain themselves by finding the multiple references to various painters or sculptors that are visible through Ortega's possessions (Braque, Calder, Mondrian, to name a few). The lighting and shading changes constantly over the hour that Angela spends in the flat and sets a breathtaking ambiance. The writing of Angela's diary is good, and the plot unfolds slowly, but surely, leading to an ending that I personally found pleasant and quite unexpected.

The world building is also impressive: we can see that the developers took time to research South American history (there is a strong parallel with the 70s in Chile) and culture, and enjoyed revisiting decades of design and architecture. The soundtrack, composed by Austin Wintory with numerous collaborations from fans that helped raise funds in the Kickstarter, is diverse and ranks from jazz to traditional folk songs, and even includes an entire requiem by an imaginary Anchurian composer that is inspired by Bach's work. From my point of view, it really did play a key role in creating this peculiar, enthralling atmosphere.

I didn't experience many technical problems, only a few glitches when Angela has to choose between warm and neutral actions, and some difficulties with the Steam overlay. Unfortunately, I doubt Tale of Tales will release a patch to correct these malfunctions since they are now working on other projects than video games.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend [i]Sunset[/i] if you don't like games that take their time and are very character-driven. On the other hand, if you enjoy admiring art and subtle characterization, then I would advise you to let yourself sink in the atmosphere of this admirable game. It is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031477253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1460984761}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051038508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1590583132}
review: Aún y leer sobretodo reviews malas sobre el juego, decidí comprarlo, y despues de pasarme la historia puedo decir que aún y muy corto, el estilo visual del juego y los sonidos estan muy pulidos. Si buscas un juego relajante y con unos personajes bastante bien desarrollados para la brevedad de la historia, no dudes en probarlo, eso si, solo si lo puedes comprar por 5€ +-, 20€ por el juego es un robo aún y que me haya gustado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067659307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1458672108}
review:
Jeu narratif très particulier. Et donc à ne pas mettre entre toute les mains. Gamer avide d'action, passe ton chemin.
Le rythme est lent et, personnellement, j'étais un peu frustrée de ne connaître mon personnage que durant cette heure de ménage par semaine. Cependant c'est une manière subtile de raconter une histoire, ou du moins de transmettre une ambiance. Je recommanderai par contre d'y jouer une heure par-ci par-là. A enchaîner les journées plus ou moins chargées, on se lasse un peu quand même.
Sinon prise en main intuitive. J'ai appréciée que le timer ne se mette en route la plupart du temps qu'en fonction des actions entreprises. (ayant un mauvais sens de l'orientation vidéoludique, cela m'a bien aidé.
La musique est vraiment très chouette. Utilisée de manière réaliste, vous n'en profiterez qu'à l'aide de disque.

En conclusion, je dirais que c'est un bon jeu d'ambiance. Pas tellement narratif d'ailleurs (pê plus en fonction des succès dévérouillés). Mais sympa et relativement court (10h environ). Même si la durée me semblait judicieuse, rapport au rythme.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019875885', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1457003159}
review:
I'm so sorry to post a negative review, but I honestly have no idea what I did for 5 hours. The story wasn't deep enough to warrant such a slow pace, and I kept waiting for a big reveal somewhere. 

I enjoy similar games that have been dubbed walking simulators, but this just never pulled me in, and I was exhausted and relieved to have finally finished it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025802559', 'num_games_owned': 2409, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1456434824}
review:
It's hard to say it's a good game, hard to say it's bad, most definitely it is unique. I have enjoyed previous ToT games more and I knew Sunset will be a tough one. 
Sunset is driven by amazing narration, that made me feel emotions towards absent Gabriel and imposed a strange connection with the penthouse. But I also felt that at some point this excellent narration just broke it's legs and I wasn't interested anymore. Postomodern discourse was compelling, but was it enough to fill the blank spaces? The same with the apartement - beautiful, but slayed by the bad optimalisation and frame rate drops. 
On the brighter side, I sympathize strongly with Angela, one can rarely find this inteligent character in video games. 

Nevertheless, I liked the experience and I plan to read some of the books left by Ortega. Sunset raises some important questions on art, equality, relations between society and government and standard of living - and I hope for that reason it will be remembered,

author: {'steamid': '76561198061091469', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1456318371}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976138338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1456258499}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995749658', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 1565, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1486063770}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005357441', 'num_games_owned': 1909, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1456116185}
review:
Easily the most outlandish war game I've seen, obviously.

I liked what it tried to do and looking at it solely from story / art concepts I felt:
-Progressed poorly at parts
-Emotions and events were never well tied together.
-Art and music were great tools
-She never should have met him and more - I shouldn't have waited for nothing just to be left out.
-Hated the happy ending (based on my choices, maybe)

From a gameplay standpoint:
-Very boring
-Very slow
-The text, humming, and overall content got old really fast
-A lot of very obvious bugs and design flaws that show little testing was done (objects thru walls, dead characters in clearly seen text)


TLDR: A very different concept that I knew was going to suck based on review videos. I picked this up only for the solid 100 achievements list - as that is what I enjoy. I liked the art (not the graphics or effects) and I liked half the music. The idea was interesing, the game is weak.
