author: {'steamid': '76561197970673973', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1432547941}
review:
Well this game looked very promising but in my short 40 minute experience it really didn't deliver on what it promised. There is little to no interaction with objects in the world and the story is solely told through a voice over, which after a while becomes monotonous and boring. 

I would have liked there to be more story telling to be uncovered through notes, objects so it makes you feel rewarded for exploring the environment. The tasks of cleaning the place just seem arbitrary after a while. The story is OK but I felt after awhile just frustrated and bored.

It is a cool concept and they obviously took a risk and if I didn;t get a review copy of the game, I think I would feel a little hard done by spending 20$ on this. But if you are into that kind of thing its worth a try, if not you could check out my playthrough! 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474154175

author: {'steamid': '76561198077575940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1436097318}
review:
There are maybe some kind of "mini-spoiler" in my review, but i think it doesen't matter. I don't think that there is the right and only solution in the game so my choises are very unimportent for the gameplay.
At first. I really liked the game. I can't explain it, Sunset is.. not a usual game. its different. It works with a kind of soft skills. there is no hectic, no kind of action in this game and the mechanic is quite simple, right. but it makes me think. i finished the game 2 days before and i still remeber situations. yesterday i started it again. its a mix. on the one side you get in touch with the military szene outside the window. with all the danger, the bombs and war. Angela is woried about her brother who is a kind of rebell. on the other side you comunicate with mr. ortega. i get warm with him. than comes the situation, where i should decides what to do. should i do something what might brings mr. ortega in danger? is that really a thing i could decide?

I am very happy, that i bought the game. this is my first review and i only write it because there are quite many bad ones. Sunset is not a game for anybody. the theme is special. but i must say, normely i hated war-szenarios. i'm more a kind of happy-ever-after-type. But for a person like me it is a nice confrontation with this theme. i startet to identify with angela. and i was a little bit upset, when i finished the game. it is like reading a book and make some desisions for the protagonist. it gave me a good feeling. and that is enough for me. :)

oh, i played the game in english with german subtitles, and it worked very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992192827', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1435673417}
review:
This was more of an interactive artistic experience, rather than a traditional game. 
If you're expecting typical gameplay, this isn't it. Mechanics are simple, you work as a housekeeper, each day your time is limited to one hour. You can do your work, or not, I thought it was interesting that you had to balance what your character had to do for work, and what "you" as the player wanted to do - in this case, find out more about the story through diary entries. These entries only appear when you sit in a specific chair, and time progresses faster when you are sitting down.
It definetly has a slow burn to it, but I thought that the character's performance was excellent. I also absolutely LOVED the music, as it is written and composed by Austin Wintory (I've you've played Journey, you'll know how beautiful it is.)

I played this on a Mac, I'm not sure if it may just be my set up (it more than met minimum requirements) but the game ran horribly, even on low settings. I haven't tested it on a windows computer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037270831', 'num_games_owned': 1032, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1670, 'last_played': 1435052161}
review:
Firstly, this review is independent of any opinons I have of the developers and their opinions.

I feel like this game is somewhat under appreciated. It's a game that you have to value and appreciate for its mood, story, and the methods in which they tell this story. I'm not the type to be into games that are overly preachy, which this game's dialog can be a little more of, but I found the way in which you unveil the story to be a lot of fun. Every day you're given a set of chores that you can do in different manners: warmly or coldly. The choices you make affect how your employer, Ortega, feels about you as a housekeeper and a person. 

SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT

The story of the revolution and political climate is expressed through the entire environment. Nothing about this game is explicitly spoonfed to you. You listen to the gunfire, watch the skyline fill with smoke, observe the newspaper headlines scattered around the apartment, and so much more. It's a complete experience that isn't for people who are waiting to have a story thrown in their faces. 

I rather liked the writing in the game, as it felt personal and the way someone of that era and background would be talking. I never had any problems with doing the chores, except for one day in which it was actually impossible to do everything listed (this is intentional, as Ortega will note the following day). I was even able to do more than what was asked of me by actually being a housekeeper and maintaining the home, such as changing the date on the calendar and turning on the lights every day.

Overall I thought this game delivered everything I expected it to when I kickstarted it. Yes, it is not a game for everyone, but I loved it anyways. I played it twice over: once doing whatever the heck I wanted and second to actually try to romance Ortega through my chores and replies to his notes. I wouldn't hesitate to play it again and take the time to explore more of Angela's thoughts and narrative.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982052071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1432241161}
review: Sunset explores some really cool ideas, a lot of it shines not in overt mechanics but in the subtle interplay of the conversation between the developer and the player through those mechanics. Brew some coffee late on a rainy night and give this one a play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024253308', 'num_games_owned': 1159, 'num_reviews': 577, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1435016680}
review:
Σημειωτέον πως η δημιουργός εταιρεία, Tale of Tales, ανακοίνωσε προχθές το κλείσιμό της, κατόπιν της εμπορικής αποτυχίας του Sunset. Διαβάζοντας την αποχαιρετιστήρια επιστολή των developers, μπορεί κανείς να συμμεριστεί τον πόνο τους και να τους ευχηθεί κάθε καλή τύχη στα μελλοντικά τους εγχειρήματα, αλλά παίζοντας το Sunset, το μόνο συμπέρασμα στο οποίο μπορεί να φτάσει, είναι πως πράγματι, η συγκεκριμένη ιδέα δεν θα έπρεπε να έχει υλοποιηθεί ποτέ ως διαδραστική φαντασία. Σαν πειραματικό φίλμ μικρού μήκους, ενδεχομένως να παρουσίαζε μεγαλύτερο ενδιαφέρον. Σαν παιχνίδι όμως, απευθύνεται σε ένα τόσο ειδικό και περιορισμένο κοινό, που είναι αδύνατον να το φανταστείς ως κάτι διαφορετικό από αποτυχημένο πείραμα ύφους.

Διαβάστε περισσότερα στο www.ragequit.gr

author: {'steamid': '76561198036923897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 838, 'last_played': 1435289029}
review:
A beautiful game that will put you in the main character's skin more tangibly than most games i've played. Beautiful story, original mechanics (being a housekeeper/bystander during a revolution) and interesting message.

The game really shines in its atmosphere. You'll arrive each day before sunset to clean the apartment and the apartment would naturally evolve, like any apartment after a week. You'll grow to really love that apartment. Know its rooms, its nooks and crannies. You'll get to know your employer and his habits, his interests and concerns. The story will really begin when he'll leave you your first note thanking you for your hard work. You spent most of the game alone in that apartment eager to read his notes to find out what he wants to tell you or what he was thinking. 

I admit, the social justice themes get old after a few hours into the game. Yeah, war is bad, we get it, but it gets really stale. Luckily, you can avoid all that by avoiding writing the diary. I think the criticism this game has been getting is unfair - the game is quite good.

The story is disjointed at times though... some things don't make any sense and will leave your head scratching. Clearly written by amateurs. Nonetheless, it's a better story than a close equivalent Gone Home for example.

Overall, it's definitely worth it if you're looking for a different game like Gone Home and are interested in some social justice/anti war monologues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086151669', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1434694357}
review:
http://niveloculto.com/sunset-analisis-critica-review/

Mientras estaba en la universidad tuve un compañero de piso, Iago, que me contó una vez lo mucho que le gustaba fregar los platos. No bromeaba. Quizás no lo disfrutaba lo suficiente como para fregar los de los demás por más que yo intentase persuadirlo, pero sí como para encontrar en ese ritual al que dedicaba una hora cada semana (no esperes que en un piso universitario alguien friegue más de una vez cada siete días) algún tipo de remanso de paz en el que ponía en orden sus pensamientos mientras realizaba una actividad mecánica que no requería mayor esfuerzo intelectual. No lo entendí en ese momento. No lo entendí hasta que me vi en una situación particular; encontrarme a un conocido en el supermercado y acabar haciendo la compra juntos me molestó mucho más de lo razonablemente esperable, algo inexplicable tratándose de alguien de cuya compañía tiendo a disfrutar muchísimo. Pero el hecho es que dicho encuentro interrumpió mi relajante sesión de vagar entre secciones sin un orden concreto, con mis pensamientos salvaguardados por la protección que otorgan unos auriculares más grandes que mi propia cabeza, fantaseando con los maravillosos platos que malograría en un futuro próximo o rumiando sobre los problemas de la vida mundana. Hasta ese momento no me di cuenta de lo mucho que disfrutaba yo haciendo la compra, y entendí perfectamente a Iago con sus platos, su Fairi y su estropajo. O a Albert Einstein aceptando un trabajo muy por debajo de sus posibilidades que no le requeriría esfuerzo alguno y le permitiría centrar sus ideas en objetivos más ambiciosos. Un poco como la protagonista de Sunset, Angela Burnes.

Angela está en una situación con la que no soñaba. Tras dejar su Baltimore natal en busca de mayor aceptación y crecimiento personal, se encuentra en un país y en medio de un conflicto que ni le van ni le vienen, con la perspectiva de tener que aceptar un trabajo con el que seguramente no fantaseaba cuando se graduó en la universidad. Una vez por semana Angela deberá pasar una hora limpiando el apartamento de Gabriel Ortega, un hombre del que al principio sabe tanto como nosotros, nada, y he ahí donde el juego muestra todo su potencial, dándote a conocer a un personaje, Gabriel, por medio de su casa y lo que en ella encontramos. Mejor aún, el segundo personaje, Angela, se nos dará a conocer mediante sus propias reflexiones ante lo que va pasando ante nuestros ojos. Porque como yo en el super, Iago en el fregadero o Einstein en la oficina, Angela tiene mucho tiempo para pensar, lo que convierte un trabajo precario en una oportunidad para poner en práctica su libertad para fisgonear y una voz con la que opinar y expresar su personalidad. Una personalidad no estática, ni inmóvil, ni impasible; seremos nosotros los que moldeemos a Angela y su relación con un hombre al que nunca vemos por medio de nuestras acciones. No grandes decisiones, sino pequeñas elecciones a priori intrascendentes. Gabriel deja su casa, vuelve y, mientras ha estado fuera, alguien ha estado ahí, limpiando, y él se forma una opinión de quién es esa mujer en función del color que ella haya escogido para pintar la pared o el álbum que haya dejado en el tocadiscos, la forma en que haya ordenado los libros o la colcha que haya puesto en la cama. Todo ello genera un diálogo único entre dos personajes de mundos totalmente distintos, tanto, que nunca se ven y que, sin embargo, interaccionan hasta tener el uno en el otro un gran impacto.

Es seguramente este concepto lo más brillante de un juego que, sin embargo, nos quiere contar una historia mucho mayor, la de una revolución, un régimen dictatorial, una situación mucho más grande que las personas que son parte de ella. Pero lo hace desde la intimidad de las dudas humanas, de tener que escoger entre lo que quieres y lo que crees que es justo, de disfrutar de la vida o tener una conciencia limpia. Hay mucha reflexión subyacente en Sunset; el papel del arte y las diferentes formas de interpretarlo, por ejemplo, tiene una presencia recurrente que, a su vez, se ve reflejada en la propia dirección artística del juego; el apartamento de Sunset es un lugar que fácilmente recordarás, pero más lo harás cuando te acerques a una ventana para ver la columna de humo que una explosión en la ciudad ha provocado y un traicionero juego de luces te devuelva tu propio reflejo y el del apartamento de Gabriel. Te preguntarás si ha sido premeditado o pura casualidad, y ahí reside parte de la magia: el diseño artístico del videojuego no debería limitarse a lo que puede ser plasmado en un artwork.

No puedo decir que sea perfecto, que sea siempre fácil detectar todas las opciones posibles por culpa de una interfaz muy mejorable, que el argumento y el desarrollo consigan mantener siempre el interés o que esta historia vaya a motivar a la mayoría de jugadores a seguir adelante hasta conocer el final. Es un juego denso, sí, y se pueden discutir su argumento o sus mecánicas, pero su narrativa es un paso adelante. Sunset planta una semilla que no termina de florecer aquí, pero que lo hará, o eso espero. Se lo compara con Gone Home y creo que no tienen nada que ver, pero es un ejemplo perfecto para ver en qué falla y en qué triunfa: en Gone Home nos montamos una historia en nuestra cabeza mediante lo que nos encontramos en una casa vacía únicamente por medio de la exploración. Sunset falla al intentar lo mismo: su mundo es bonito pero corto en detalles e interacción: no nos enteraríamos de nada si no fuese por la reflexión de Angela cada día al subir en el ascensor y la forma en que está diseñado hace fácil pasar elementos importantes por alto. La cuestión está en que este problema perjudica al juego mucho menos de lo que podríamos esperar porque, como ya dije, el ejemplo de Gone Home no es bueno. El apartamento de Sunset no nos quiere contar una historia; su objetivo es servir las herramientas para la interacción entre dos personas, y es por eso que cierra habitaciones para que no perdamos tiempo explorando lo irrelevante o nos da pistas de a dónde ir para hacer avanzar la trama. Y esa interacción está tan bien recreada, es tan suave y natural, que tardas en percibirla. No la ves hasta que encuentras un vinilo con un post-it que dice “pensé que te gustaría”.

Sunset funciona mejor como muestra de lo que el videojuego como elemento narrativo puede llegar a hacer que como muestra de lo que nos encontraremos cuando lleguemos a ese punto. Como Gabriel Ortega, nos abre las puertas y nos deja echar un vistazo, fisgonear, pero espera que sean otros quienes pongan la casa en orden. Debería dar que hablar y que pensar, ojalá a alguien con talento para dar el siguiente paso, de tener la siguiente gran idea, quién sabe, quizás mientras barre el suelo o tiende la ropa.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974206234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1435014226}
review:
The positive: Really interesting premise, setting and art style. I was invested in the story despite its unusual presentation. I appreciated that it wasn't about aliens or zombies or hitmen. When the game started and I realized I would be doing chores I was skeptical, but it won me over pretty quickly.

The negative: I'm really forgiving when it comes to clunkiness, especially in indie titles, but this one just wore me down fast. After a while I just couldn't ignore the flakey controls and poor optimization, and I opted to watch a lets play instead of actually playing it (Hence the extremely low # of hours played). If this were an Early Access game and I could expect these issues to improve I'd say absolutely give it a look, but as a finished title it's just shy of worth it. I've got to give it a thumbs down unless you're specifically into unusual game design.

I'm actually looking forward to the next game from these developers. They've convinced me that they can craft a fun experience out of unique elements. I'm hoping it's something in a similar style, just a more polished technically.

(Side note - Not really a plus or minus, just something to keep in mind if you're sensitive to motion sickness - this is the only FPS I've ever played that has made me feel nauseated. My wife couldn't watch more than a few minutes before almost throwing up. Pretty weird.)

[Edit: After writing this I checked out the developer to see what else they were up to. Turns out they've shut down. That's a damn shame.]

author: {'steamid': '76561197972294032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1435107224}
review:
This isn't a good game, even when you come at it with an open mind. As a hidden object Gone Home-like, it fails on many parts due to its poor communication/UI and limited, shallow level. As a narrative experience, I'm finding myself constantly confused by the flip-flopping protagonist and the seemingly random thoughts that don't have much of a link to what's happening outside the window. Coupled with some very long and grating diary entries and a LOT of filler content to artificially increase its length, this isn't going to get recommended.

At its full retail price it's insanely overpriced, even on a 50% sale it was overpriced. The quality is just not good enough. 

As a side note, when you look at the developer's dev diary and subsequent Twitter reactions to comments about it, I just can't support Tale of Tales no matter how much they've apparently 'given' to the indie scene with their pioneering art games. They disrespect an entire medium and audience because their game flopped. It flopped because it's a poor quality game and the marketing was abysmal (a significant amount of comments say they didn't know it was out).

author: {'steamid': '76561197966874596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1435100876}
review:
In this game you do household chores while trying to get a Puerto Rican man to give you his churro.

Edit: I mean I guess you don't have to take the Dominican's tamale but at the end of the day, you're still taking care of his apartment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006926420', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1436907230}
review:
I haven't finished my first play through yet. I'm doling this game out a couple game days at a time, to give me time to reflect. There's no surges of adreniline, or pats on the head, just thought proking atmosphere that gives me the feels. Your effect on the world is delivered through voice over and change in interactions with your employer. Gabriel's apratment seems a small place to explore, but it's a lens that lends perspective out of proportion to it's size. It can be difficult to get everything on list done and still have time to journal. When I can't find a task quickly or find the covered chair (the only one you can journal in), I do get a bit frustrated. I do always try to explore as much as possible to find the various notes Gabriel leaves as well as his literary and musical offerings.
And yes, this game is horribly optimized. I suppose that's the drawback of being a game studio of two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037101776', 'num_games_owned': 3174, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1435242574}
review:
Deeply thought-provoking and open-ended game, filled with lingering thoughts, inviting intimate roleplaying. Cleverly uses a remote revolutionary setting, away from the immediate grasp, to entice finding ways to subvert situations on a microscopic scale. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mII7QXHeDFI

Love it. Weeks in game time and still discovering new tiny mechanisms that open up more events.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993008935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1435008452}
review:
Okay.. hadn't heard of this game until today when it was announced the game developers 'Tale of Tales' are closing their doors, it was hotly reported on FB by many Games News publishers/journalists.

I watched the ad and thought.. this is right up my street as far as weird indie games go.

I feel.. as other critical members have said.. it dragged on in places, however I disagree with them on the point the UI was awkward, it was simplistic and I feel like the devs must have.. this immersred you into the beautful love story the experiance became.

I'm torn whether or not to recommend this game.. the slow chunks, the painfully frustating confusion about small nothing puzzles*.. but the opposite is true.. there were moments of delight for me, seeing their love blossom ever so delicately, touched me in such a way, I might think it was real* when I forget about playing this game ten years from now. The voice acting of Tina Marie Murray was excellent, delicate and emotive. But again.. I experianced many glitches in my copy, like the controller wouldn't look properly with the right thumb stick, and then would for no reason. That kind of glitch undoes the beauty of the interface, that you are telling a intimate interactive story, when so much thought's been put in deep immersion, and then broken. This game NEEDED everything to be competently coded, not that it was bad/bad, just it need to be *perfect* to keep those vibes going/flowing I also had 'wild textures' and no outside at one point. But I turned some settings off and it seemed to fix it.

The art is superb.. the styling, the lighting was odd, too much haze and neon in there, that obscured too much of the game.

The plot.. is a spoiler fest but.. on the whole I enjoyed it, I didn't like the scribbling noise she made in her diary, this would have been much better voice acted, as we are ment to be hearing her thoughts as no one else is there when she speaks, so logically this is her mind. It would have eased me.

I dont know what to say.. the bad bits were *bad* and convserly those slim moments.. touched you with lasting delight, As a love story.. I think it was much better than the swash of love films that are out there, as 'a one woman play'.. *this* medium of game is far better showing the great story than a play or a movie.

I have no idea if this was bad or good game. o.O

------------
*The clickable areas for controller were miniscule and/or akward.
*real= like a movie, book or play.. or even a story someone told me once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027483054', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1432830325}
review: I said "recommended" but only because there's no " Only if you really like walking simulators" and even with that in mind I'm still not sure. I bought it pretty much on release and played through entire game once. Thing to note is that the game have different endings based in the way you play. Each day you have a set of task to complete, and you can complete them in one of two ways, influencing the story. And to be honest I felt like the game mechanic was in the way of story telling, and the fact that the story just basically stops halfway through the game just to pick up at the and does not help, I actually felt like I'm doing chores. There are some cool thing to discover every other day and just nice touches here and there, ( especially all the books you can find, I really liked those) but it's just not enough. I don't know, at the end of the day: Pick up if you're into walking simulators and it's on some sort of sale, otherwise you probably want to skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966549184', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1433544690}
review:
If lots of people buy this now could it still save Tale of Tales? Buy this now.

Look at those georgous sceen shots. This is a game that's trying to do something more interesting than almost anything else around. And also Austin 'The Banner Saga', 'Journey' Wintory has totally surpassed himself here. Without question the most sublime videogame soundtrack I've ever heard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005858799', 'num_games_owned': 904, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1432250616}
review: An excellent story driven game that weaves a huge story of revolution and rebellion from the viewpoint of one woman in one apartment through her communication with its owner. A masterpiece of storytelling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012191364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1434873790}
review: Sunset is bold as it turns a seemingly boring "game concept" into an emotionally engrossing journey that consumes you with it's story. It has a been too long since the ending of a game has left me breathless, confused, and wanting more. It has been too long since a game has had a story so good that the intentionally mundane gameply just sucks you in more and makes you feel like a real, normal person, standing in the middle of a story. The game sends deep messages and shivers up your spine anytime something story relevant happens. It has been too long since a game has made me, or anyone who has played it, this emotionally consumed with a story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017286048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1434742591}
review:
Чужой дом. Каково это - постоянно в нем находиться, ощущать присутствие владельца - оставленные в неожиданных местах записки, смятое одеяло, переставленные вещи - и никогда не видеть этого человека?
    Прочитай его нечаянную записку, черкни пару слов в ответ. Ты не узнаешь и не почувствуешь этого, но в твое отсутствие записку прочтут, и, возможно, через неделю тебя будет ждать следующая. А может быть - нет, как и привычного "списка дел" - и тебе просто нужно будет продолжать приходить, поддерживать ощущение дома в залитых закатным солнцем аппартаментах, учиться играть на пианино, писать одну за другой записи в дневнике... желать такому знакомому незнакомцу удачи, готовить ему ужин, сжигать газеты... и ждать, что он все-таки придет.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997152026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1434316682}
review:
- 5,5/10 - не для всех! :-\

- в стране, психологию которой определяют закаты, перевернуть все с ног на голову можно лишь дожив до утра ... игры студии Tale of Tales всегда оказываются не тем, чем они кажутся на первый взгляд - но чаще даже играми не оказываются - вот и здесь - на поверхности тут опосредованная, будоражащая кровь шпиономания в декорациях латиноамериканской диктатуры - в глубине же, все это смахивает на симулятор впадения в транс сквозь личность темнокожей уборщицы - изо дня в день бесконечно повторяющиеся, монотонные, безвкусные телодвижения в квартире министра культуры местного "режима" должны подвести тебя к паре сюжетных ходов под покровом интерактива, направление движения истории в которых ты, в идеале, уже должен будешь выбрать не раздумывая, валясь от усталости и погрязнув в мелочах - серьезные последствия через простые движения - может быть на этом и строится мир, какую бы историю ты не попытался о нем рассказать? ... допустим, главная философская подоплека тут и не в этом, но толковой "игры" здесь опять не получилось - просто, чтобы "играть" с описанными в этом проекте темами и чувствами - нужно больше динамики и внимания к мелочам, изобретательности и характера, раз уж единственным способом общения между людьми тут выбран контакт с принадлежащими им вещами, вещами которые их окружают, которые становятся их сутью - тут же балом правит какая-то вселенская ограниченность во всем, наполненная околокультурно напыщенными "фи!" и "хо-хо!" ... но романтика "игры не для всех" тут определенно имеется! *множественные технические недоработки тоже требуют особого душевного настроя, ага!* :-\

author: {'steamid': '76561198030083787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1434569977}
review:
This was a very bold game in it's exploration of the relationships people have with other people, art, war and larger society. I think the most beautiful thing about this game was it's tribute paid to classical art. The soundtrack is gorgeous and many times while playing the game I would just sit back and listen. But for that reason, it's not a good game to play if you're looking for something more fast-paced. There is no action inside of the apartment, you are in a safe environment onlooking the destruction of the city around you.

I also didn't realise I could press Y or N (or click above or below the mouse) to perform actions positively or negatively until the very end of the game. Hilariously, I sent my boss rude messages without even noticing I could change them, wondering why my character was so mean-spirited. I'm looking forward to playing a second time and seeing how the gameplay changes with a positive relationship with my boss.

All in all, I absolutely loved it because of it's explorations of art, philosophy and human relationships (also a POC, female protagonist!!) but was not impressed with it's tedious gameplay. I would suggest this for people who enjoyed games like Telltale games (Walking Dead, Game of Thrones etc), Gone Home, The Novelist, Papers Please, The Stanely Parable and Dear Esther.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961723705', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1434147256}
review:
Glad I played it - but also now glad I've finished it.

I'll try to keep it short, as others have covered many of the points I wanted to make below.

Some positives I took away from it:
1) You play the entire game in a flat. By yourself. And it makes you feel part of something.
No cut scenes, no narrative, you're just in the flat - but manages to give a fantastic sense of 'world' outside.
2) I've no idea if what I did mattered. Normally in a game you're popped into a world and told to change it.
My world here definitely changed - but I've got absolutely no idea if *I* changed it. 
I 'did things' from turning on hundreds of light switches to faxing off secret plans - and 'other things' happened as I did so. 
I'm reasonably sure some of my actions influenced my employer, but the impact of that, on the world he inhabits - I've genuinely no idea.
That's actually quite an impressive mechanic, managing to give me a sensation of layered influence over a stack of things, I never see.

My negatives:
Really just concerned with that last point. I turned on so so many light switches. I developed my own routines of how I'd go through the flat. I got obsessed with ensuring lights were on  and the calendar was updated each day - and got genuinely pissed off when I realized I'd not updated it, prior to starting a job that would run out the clock for that game-day.

I've come away with the feeling the devs were trying to make a point (maybe they weren't and it's a gaming Rorschach test, but I digress). However, I feel they made their point, but in doing so they overlooked my enjoyment. 
Bluntly, for better or worse, most of us play games to feel empowered in some way. It's intellectually interesting to demonstrate this doesn't have to be the case - but maybe takes away from the enjoyment of the paying subjects.
I imagine there's a spreadsheet, or stack of post-its on a board, where the "story" was plotted out in abstract, and dutifully mapped into the game day by day - but then nobody with fresh eyes gave feedback.

Games it reminded me of *opens list of Indie-hits from last couple of years* were:
Gone Home, for the solitary exposition in a fixed environment - although think there's still a sweet spot to be found between the magnificent lack of environmental-progression in Sunset, and Gone Home's "you've unlocked a room"
Stanley Parable, for messing with tropes - just Stanley gave you a quick pay-off on challenging them, Sunset lets you indulge and simply leaves you hanging. Conversely though, Stanley never felt it had any depth.
Lifeless Planet, for me loving the concept and execution - but having got the point, just wishing there'd been an editor involved in the process to wrap it up sooner.
Papers Please, this is a late edit, but finally worked out what it's missing is what this game had - the balance between the mundane job, and allowing you to make exceptions. PP didn't quite have the world, but the mechanic was less obtuse.

Re-reading, I feel the review comes across as negative, which wasn't my intention. 
It's a unique game I'm glad I played, but just can't help feeling it could have been a bit better. Just a slight bit more "gamier"

author: {'steamid': '76561197985686641', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1484525864}
review:
Perhaps you heard of Sunset, even backed it on Kickstarter, and imagined life as a houseworker in a hot climate with fierce political tensions. You'd work for this man, cleaning his house, making many choices and experiencing a riveting narrative throughout. You will be disappointed.

Creators always have to think of the best medium for any creation, be it music, art, games, fiction. In this respect, Sunset's a token videogame. It should have been a web app or mobile game. You walk through a 3D environment and click your buttons just like a videogame, but the connection is so minimal that it's clear you're here for the story: which is just only passable. You're expected to search the apartment for clues as to what's going on, but the process of doing so just isn't enjoyable.

I set my walk speed to high so I could breeze through the chores. This renders Angela as a high-speed automaton responding binarily (two choices) to each action -- and this wasn't even communicated well. Where you'd expect to hover over an object and hit Y or N, (yes or no for positive/negative? sure!) you apparently have to move your cursor north and south of the object? Anyway, it took me a good few minutes to figure out how to water the plants one Day. I'd prefer to just tick an optional setting of, "highlight all important objects" so we can do away with the illusion that the game should be immersive.

The 1970's filter over the screen held charm for about 30 seconds. It's annoying in the day. At night, the apartment can become hard to see, and damn if I'm going to waste my precious (and pointlessly timed) minutes turning on each light so I can see. Another optional toggle for the filter would be appreciated, and I have a suspicion that it's cause of a few performance issues people have. 

On that note, it is presently a little jittery in regards to performance. War games employ explosions, many NPCs everywhere, intense calculations, reflections, etc. and they still run better than Sunset, which takes place in a single apartment.

I will await a patch for further play. But no patch will avert the reality: they could have dedicated significantly more time to writing more options for these notes and other choices in the game, if only Sunset weren't a videogame. It plays like a web app could.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186396395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1435120198}
review:
I'm only two hours in.,.. I don't know where the game ends but so far after a dozen or more apartment visits it feels like a whole lot of nothing going on. The character ruminates on events happening outside of her control, but I don't know if there is a challenge or fail state. It just keeps moving forward, even without completing all the apartment work. So I'm not getting much out of this right now. You do only two things: Look around and "Click 'x' to sympathize", to borrow from Call of Duty Advanced Warfare. And the looking around is excruciating because for  a game with little environmental scenery this game moves like a sloth. Even on lowest graphic settings it has the same frame rate drops as the highest setting. It's clear that this game needs graphical performance tuning.

(ADDENDUM, June 22): It turns out that I'm missing half of the ideas in the game just by doing the chores alone. Angela expresses her thoughts in a the form of a diary and the way to see that is to sit down in the one lounge chair with a sheet over it. There are a lot of striking ideas being expressed in this moment that it is a shame if you miss it... And it's easy to miss because if you're out of time then you won't sit.


(FINAL UPDATE, JUNE 24): Finished the game. There is an intellectualism in the writing, but the game is boring and frustrating. I enjoyed playing the vinyl records because they broke up the otherwise dire soundscape. Moving around was always a problem and on more than one occasion I found a chore item impossible to do: Thoroughly scoured the apartment but didn't find the objective. I appreciate the idea of trying new things in gaming, and there is one crucial diary entry that illuminated why this game exists, but otherwise the game was thematically all over the place and full of mood swings. It felt more like a gaming transposition of someone's blog than an actual story. In that regard I felt as though I had been tricked into someone else's indulgence.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981412938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1440950135}
review:
in Brief: absolutely no gameplay, except for walking (slowly) from a point to a point in bright 70s decor. Story's dull and progresses (very slowly to the uneventful end) through text messages, paper articles and heroine's monologing. Authors should have written the book or the script for a drama.

I realy don't want to bash on artsy / indy stuff, but this "game" is plain dull, i played through it as i was doing awfully borring chore. The worst is the lack of interaction and vague consequences of actions – I didn't have the feel that I affect the story or that my presence matters. Everything you do is pushing buttons. And when the heroine said that the war is over, a huge boulder fell from my shoulders and I felt the real relief to know that this torture have ended. That's the most powerful emotion this game brought from me.

I'm sure there are slim number of people who would like the concept of it, and maby find the ideas game bombarding the player with smart and insightful, but they banal and beaten to the death since the 1st men got hit with a stick.

Also, the game performance is awful.

You want narrative driven games – try Telltale, at least, these are exciting and manage to show more than one location with only character.


P.S. I was playing in it, 'cause I was assigned to. Finished it 2 times (the most fun I got was when I was hunting for hidden books and right behind it – keeping the calendar to date).

---

UPD 06/23/15: My sincere condolences to the developers, it's always a tragedy when yet another studio goes down the drain, but they brought it on themselves: reaching for wider audience without understanding it preferences; wasting money on pr, that doesn't affect true auditory; copying others and not trying to be true to themselves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011697046', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1433527936}
review:
This is my 30second Sunset Review:

https://youtu.be/m5oNv2EJBEI

It’s the 70’s and there’s a revolution brewing in the country. But that’s out there, beyond the safety of the house. You’re just a humble maid. Your boss however is none other than General Ortega, an influential political figure.

You talk with him through brief notes and perform mundane, but not meaningless chores, since the way you do them add up and indirectly impact your relationship, the plot and ultimately the whole country.

We’ve never experienced anything like this before, although the pace sometimes seems too slow.

A beautiful new way to tell a story that gets

8 mops out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031757552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1433610477}
review:
[b]In Brief[/b]
[b]Sunset[/b] is a unique, profound narrative game about art, and people, and it made me fall in love.

[b]Most valuable resource:[/b] The unique, incredibly well thought-out use of gameplay.
[b]Of interest to:[/b] people interested in character, relationships, philosophy, and art.

[b]Tale of Tales[/b] have a history of very cleverly using gameplay elements to construct an experience.  These are the same people who made [b]The Path[/b], which messed with your expectations about player choice, and game advancement, and [b]Bientot L'ete[/b], a multiplayer game about loneliness.  With [b]Sunset[/b] though they have excelled themselves.

It's the 1970s, and you are a black American who left her homeland for the Latin American nation of Anchuria for personal reasons, and now finds herself, engineering degree and all, working as a maid for a rich member of the ruling elite.  Gameplay is very straightforward: once a week you arrive at his house, receive a list of chores, and have an hour to do them.  Although you're on the clock, the game doesn't feel like a time trial; it's more about making choices.  The game is repetitive, but in a completely engaging way; each day is the same house, the same basic routine, with different chores, but very quickly that stops being the point as you slowly learn more about the man you are working for, a man you've never met but whose house you routinely occupy.

Against a backdrop of a military dictatorship, the game has a lot to say about progress and tradition, about art, and people, and war.  It uses religion, and art, and music as its motifs, and the diary entries and commentary of this person as whom you play is subtle, and gentle, tangential to the points the game is making, letting you think about it, think it through.  A lot of art games that have something to say jam it down your throat, but [b]Sunset[/b] is happy to just talk, just show you things, and let you experience people, and then think about it and see to what conclusions you come yourself.  Because it isn't forcing the issue the game can be quite high-brow without pushing people away with pretension.

There are collectibles in the form of a selection of literature that pertains to the issues raised during the game, and obscure music discs.  The collectibles hint at some of the ideas in the story, but they also make you feel like the house you clean is occupied by someone else; you get to know him a little by his books, which is, again, such a subtle thing.  That he leaves these books and records out at times feels deliberate, like he wants you to see what he is reading for some reason, to share in his music, building a strangely, unexpectedly strong connection between you and this person you've not yet met.  This game could easily feel sterile, with its modern house and its simplicity of location, but instead these little touches make the experience instead feel intimate.

The game has one hundred achievements.  I don't believe the developers did this without thought.  For me, at least, finishing the game with 71 achievements made me feel like I still didn't fully know Ortega, which, given how the story progresses, is quite a profound way to end.  If this was the intention then these developers are artists who paid great attention to every detail of the gaming experience.

There is so much more to say about this game, but I want to avoid spoiling anything you may take from the game through your own experience of playing it.  If this sort of narrative experience sounds like something you might enjoy, take a punt and play [b]Sunset[/b].  All art is subjective, but for me, there is every chance that this delicately crafted story will be my game of the year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049041798', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1508618966}
review:
Difficile de juger un titre comme Sunset, qui cherche avant tout à explorer de nouvelles façons de raconter une histoire. Si la narration est effectivement intéressante puisqu'elle nous propose d'incarner un personnage secondaire, la technique d'un autre âge gêne l'immersion et les sessions limitées en temps désamorcent le plaisir de la découverte. Le contexte original et la mise en avant d'un sujet aussi inhabituel dans le jeu vidéo que l'art nous poussent tout de même à recommander Sunset aux curieux.

[url=http://indius.org/tests/sunset/] Le test complet sur Indius [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198019651249', 'num_games_owned': 1407, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1432332972}
review:
Ordinarily, you would think of style over substance as a pejorative. What I find so interesting about Sunset, though, is the extent to which style literally [i]becomes[/i] substance, successfully carrying the narrative by virtue of what you can tell it is attempting to be rather than what it actually is.

Is Angela's characterization all over the place, particularly with regards to the lack of impact that your decisions have in her relationship with Gabriel? Definitely. Is there much in the way of understanding why their flirtation really kicks off to begin with? Not really. Do totalitarian governments identify and take a serious interest in the immediate families of celebrity rebel leaders? Certainly. Does it make a lot of sense to think of someone who works for one hour a day as an icon of proletariat grind? Nah.

I mean, why don't they just get together? You never really know.

And yet, when you look at their shared love of art through the exceptional visuals of the game, the narrative of the war that comes through Angela's words, and the overall concept of people slowly growing together through a shared sanctuary from a chaotic world, I'll bet everyone in the world would come to more or less the same exact conclusion of what this story is trying to say.

Whether you're prepared to forgive it for all that is up to you. Something that leaves so much in the sky is not really for me, I don't think, but I appreciate deeply that Sunset made me feel what I think it wanted to without having actually brought me through it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994782386', 'num_games_owned': 983, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1310, 'last_played': 1432889338}
review:
Уникальная вещь: традиционный для Tale of Tales артхаус, но теперь в соединении с настоящим геймплеем и сюжетом!

Это даже не столько адвенчура, сколько, если так можно выразиться, "артхаусный симулятор домработницы с элементами любовного романа и революционной деятельности". Напоминает "исследовательские игры", получившие в последнее время распространение на волне популярности "Dear Esther" и "Gone Home", - но, конечно же, на порядок глубже и намного красивее и увлекательнее! 

В общем, и поклонникам классических приключений, и ценителям нестандартных проектов, и просто эстетам пройти мимо "Sunset" никак нельзя.

Более подробная рецензия: http://itc.ua/articles/sunset-zakat-solntsa-nad-yuzhnoy-atlantikoy/

author: {'steamid': '76561197968328735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1432973898}
review:
Ok i did a video review, that i will post below, so ill try and just give you the cliffnotes. im going to start with the cons because thats what the majority of this "game" is made of.


CONS:
Poorly written story, with bad pacing, and amaturistice dialog
Boring and uninteresting characters, all two of them (Three if you count the brother)
The most boring and repetitive gameplay i have ever seen
Poor animations
Poor optimization (major frame rate issues)
Buggy (Lighting, clipping, and crashing are the big ones)
WAY TOO LONG (Its a boring slog that youll be forceing yourself through half way through the game)

PROS:
Good soundtrack
Interesting concept (but poorly done)
Interesting setting (70s latin america, but this wasnt taken advantage of)

so in short DONT buy this, get Gone Home. has a simmilar concept but its done so much better. yes gone home is shorter but its much more interesting. 


UPDATE:
After contacting Steam, the dev, and The Humble Store directly requesting a refund from one of the three i recived a reply. The Humble Store (the only one of the three that responed) finaly responed and in less than a week i had a full refund. Please note that I made this request before Steam's new refund program.

UPDATE 2: steam did eventualy reply but told be to talk to the humble store, and like i said humble issued a refund. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zAJZJ_ER9Jc&feature=youtu.be

author: {'steamid': '76561198042846362', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1433009362}
review:
i'll get this out of the way quickly: yes, the game has some technical issues, and it runs slowly and lags a lot on my machine.

but.

but.

i love this game. i love the story and how it is revealed, i love angela's commentary and her notes and her journal and how she isn't afraid to have her voice. i love that one has a choice as to how the characters interact and the story progresses. and i love the style, the design and the music. this game is beautiful, and i'm so happy to have supported it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971796673', 'num_games_owned': 561, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1433002817}
review:
I liked Sunset. It's not what many would consider a traditional game, even of the adventure variety. There are choices to be made that impact the relationship between Angela and Gabriel but this largely about capturing emotion of a time and place. As someone who can remember the early '70s, the game does a good job of reflecting the tumultuousnes of that time period. Angela's thoughts and feelings seem at times to swing from one side to the other, but that was the nature of that time period. This game is not a historical game in the sense of capturing actual events, but it does capture some of the  uncertainty many had back then. Today, eveyone seems so certain of their positions. Sunset is a reminder that not choice is obvious and the outcomes of our choices are not certain.

No, the game doesn't capture these things perfectly. Also, I'm of the belief that, generally speaking, games are primarily entertainment (the same as TV and movies). Detailed analysis is in the realm of books and lectures. But at times (rare, admittedly) TV, movies, and especially games because of the interactivity can capture feelings in ways that may be difficult for more precise forms to capture. Sunset reaches for and largely hits this goal. It will not be for everyone. But if you have played other Tale of Tales games or similar games like Dear Esther and enjoyed them, then you should definitely play Sunset. If you've never played any of these, but are looking for something different than the average video game, then you will not find a much better place to start than Sunset.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974002194', 'num_games_owned': 1646, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1468697790}
review:
[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Premières impressions[/u] : [/h1][/th][th]v. 0 -[/th][/tr][/table]
[h1]Huis-clos, monologue, narration ?[/h1] 
/ 🇧🇪   / Tale of Tales fait partie des meubles. Présent depuis longtemps, nombreuses productions et même quelques réussites. Peut-être les connaissez-vous pour leur titre “[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/269150/]Luxuria Superbia[/url]”. En ce qui me concerne, cela remonte au très singulier “[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/27000/]The Path[/url]”, depuis celui-là, je ne les quitte plus. 
Kickstarter sourit aux Belges, Woolfe, Divinity Orignal Sin et maintenant Sunset — qui avait dépassé et de loin son objetcif, tant mieux ! 

Sunset ne vous donnera pas ce que vous voulez, mais plutôt ce qu'il vous faut. C'est un titre d'auteur, un titre expérimental ! Les troubles d'un pays de fiction d'Amérique du Sud, un propriétaire énigmatique et absent, un penthouse obsédant. Voilà la nourriture qu'offre cette fois ToT. Le prétexte, à tout cela, c'est vous, émigrée noire américaine, qualifiée mais la vie et les règles en ont fait la régisseur de la luxueuse habitation d'un mystérieux capitaine d'industrie. 

[h1]Principe[/h1] 
Transposé dans le jeu cela donne une protagoniste à la 1re personne qui, régulièrement, se rend dans un appartement sublime pour l'entretenir en l'absence de son propriétaire. Une heure pour effectuer les tâches d'une check-list fournie à chaque fois que vous sortez de l'ascenseur dédié du lieu. Vous pensez, vous vous interrogez et décryptez ce que vous pouvez, voir, déduire ou entendre. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446597840
Sunset, comme souvent avec ToT, est un titre complexe, les conventions ordinaires du jeu s'y appliquent mais d'une manière différente. Je veux vous le recommander à tous, mais tout le monde n'est pas nécessairement disposé à recevoir le message ou à apprécier la méthode employée. Il n'en reste pas moins que ce titre (il n'est pas le seul) recèle l'idée du jeu vidéo avec beaucoup de pureté et de sincérité. Raconter et donner à ressentir quelque chose de spéciale. Sur ce point, Sunset est incontestablement le titre le plus réussi du studio. 
On ne peut pas forcer quelqu'un à ressentir quelque chose. Cependant, si l'on est assez subtil, assez audacieux et doué d'une haute maîtrise pour le sensible, on peut faire en sorte que l'esprit n'ai plus d'autre choix que de s'imposer un questionnement. C'est ce que parvient à faire Sunset avec plus ou moins d'habilité. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=450463073
[h1]Ressentir[/h1] 
La maîtrise des codes graphiques de l'époque est exemplaire — et le [url=http://anhourbeforesunset.tumblr.com/]tumblr[/url] relatant le travail artistique en amont est formidable, la quantité d'éléments du penthouse est impressionnante, tant par leur nombre que par la qualité de leur conception. Livres, tableaux, art plastique, objets du quotidien, tout varie d'une visite à l'autre et prodigue une immersion qui peut facilement dériver vers la fascination ou la contemplation. L'aspect sonore est également très bien rendu, la rumeur de la rue au bas de l'immeuble, le son étouffé d'un 33 tours dans la pièce d'à côté, la radio qui grésille doucement. Les éclairages êxtremement simples et ténus sont régulièrement saisissant. 

Tout n'est pas parfait particulièrement sur le plan technique, nombreux sont ceux qui se plaignent de problèmes de performances. Je suis aussi intrigué par les options relatives aux contrôles, 2.5D, 3D, point 'n click, mouvement libre, fov. Je me retrouve à me demander comment au juste ToT a voulu délivrer son expérience et comment rejoindre au mieux leur vision (mais je dois dire que je doute qu'ils n'aient pas mesuré ce problème lorsque les options ont été incluses). Si je me réjouis de voir que Sunset ne cède pas aux maudites sirènes des IDE 3D récentes et leur débauche de possibilités rutilantes, je me dis quelque fois que certains éléments techniques auraient mérités plus de fioritures. Les ombres, reflets, les changements de lumière. Je pointe aussi le manque de consistance du retour sur vos actions ou mouvements, la sensation de n'être qu'une caméra est parfois gênante. Quelque fois, la voix-off explicitant vos pensées se retrouve en conflit avec le sous-titres courant, déstabilisant. Heureusement, mis à part l'optimisation (qui sera forcément améliorée) rien de tout cela n'est de nature à ternir l'alchimie générale.

Si vous pouvez dépasser la peur naturelle d'une expérience aussi différente, je vous encourage vivement à lui donner une chance. Il est abouti et complet. N'oubliez pas que c'est un jeu aux frontières floues, il vous appartiendra de "jouer le jeu", de vous laisser absorber et de parvenir à faire fi d'être guidé ou d'avoir un but précis. Pour l'instant, il n'est qu'en anglais mais j'ai bon espoir qu'une traduction française lui sera donnée. 
[quote][h1]N'hésitez pas à réagir, que ce soit pour une question ou pour signaler une erreur[/h1][/quote] [table][tr][th]- -[/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/smithfield]Smithfield[/url][/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/discussions/forum/12/617328967244490669/][h1]Ajoutez-moi, si…![/h1][/url][/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/discussions/forum/12/617329150699182932/][h1]Critiques:Les règles[/h1][/url][/th][/tr][/table]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970601224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1432838037}
review:
"If we have to go to war, let's fight to re-establish the peace"

Games are constantly encouraging us to explore spaces. They offer us maps to explore, often with trinkets hidden in their most distant corners. But video game spaces have rarely felt as dynamic and worth exploring as the apartment in Sunset. It is, in a world where many games boast of their world being '31.5% larger than that other game', a relatively small place, a handful of rooms all in all. Yet over Sunset's modest running time it changes in ways both radical and subtle - changes that allow the game's narrative, characters and themes to germinate. It is worth exploring the apartment thoroughly afresh every time you leave the elevator, because it's the hidden details you'll only find if your paying attention that give this extraordinary game its depth. Book covers hint at characters' states of mind, the situation beyond the apartment walls or maybe just offer a neat little gag. Notes carefully placed out of the way allow the game's central relationship to develop, all without a word of dialogue being spoken. Eventually more radical changes fundamentally alter the mood and identity of a place that had become to feel familiar, safe... a home?

Repetition, too, is deeply ingrained in video game vocabulary, many games proudly demanding players to repeat the same tasks over and over again for typically arbitrary rewards. And repetition is key to Sunset too, but in a way that's not interested in wasting your time, but instead to use routine and passing time to expand the game's scope and depths. Every visit is the same yet different, the routine subtly varying over the course of the game. It quickly becomes apparent that the tasks assigned to Angela are of little concern to anybody involved, the 'excuse' to get this woman into an apartment for an hour a week. You'll be lulled into a comfortable rhythm, only to be legitimately surprised and excited when its disrupted - never in gaming history has a ringing phone felt so revelatory. There's an extended section in the middle of the game where very little happens for quite a while - yet it's possibly the bravest part of the game, that uses time in a way to create a sense of unease, dread, and impatience in the player and protagonist. 'Dead time' it most certainly is not, and a sharp riposte to games that artificially extended their running time for no reason at all.

Angela is an atypical video game character to say the very least. She is not defined by her race or gender, but they're an integral part to the rich thematic tapestry of Sunset. Her inner monologue, delivered in poetically brief snippets, reveal a character who develops in fascinating ways over the course of one year, her actions subtly guided by the player's decisions within the game. This is a game of binary - orange and blue - choices, but of impressively nuanced morality, aware that the subject matter being addressed here is rarely black & white.

Sunset is a game about art, about love, about freedom, about literature, about politics. It is, notably, a game about war, but addresses it from a perspective that feels unique within a wider cultural landscape, let alone video games (a medium in many ways that has developed over the years by trivialising war). Actual combat is only ever glimpsed or heard from a distance, yet it is as complete an exploration of the victims, contradictions and consequences of war has ever portrayed in an interactive medium. The characters decry the destruction and the death caused by the military, yet also find themselves conflicted by the 'necessity' of fighting. They fret over the impossibility of peace and freedom without more suffering. They reflect in horror at the consequences of their actions, while celebrating their victories. This is undoubtedly an anti-war game, but also one with a deep understanding that it's more complicated than 'war is bad'. Most importantly, nowhere does the game lecture - it asks us to ask ourselves questions to which there are no easy answers. Even Angela herself is an unreliable narrator, her point of view far from the definitive one. We can empathise without necessarily agreeing.

If we're talking about 'graphics', Sunset is imperfect - the frame rate is inconsistent, the animation occasionally wonky, and some of the assets uninspiring. Yet aesthetically it is a triumph. The more you play, the more it becomes evident that the hit to performance was a worthy compromise given the quality of the art. The impressionistic reflections, gorgeous shadows and dynamic lighting in the game make for many ravishing visual moments, many of which you will stumble across by chance. The game is presented as a perpetual magic hour, approaching twilight, complemented by the stylised light sources within the game itself (the surrealist neon yellow staircase impresses every time). The artfully applied soundtrack enhances the atmosphere, too - Austin Wintory's economically utilised compositions are fetching, while many of the game's most potent moments come from the times when you put on one of the records you find scattered about the place, and just go exploring.

Sunset is from an (almost) alternate dimension - one where video games are formally adventurous, thematically provocative, overflowing with nuance and intellect. It is a very rare breed indeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994037570', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1432893113}
review:
“Five years to get a piece of paper that says I’m an engineer. All so I can clean this man’s house,” Angela muses as she steps into the penthouse apartment for the first time. It’s spacious and empty. Gabriel Ortega, her employer, has tasked Angela to clean the floors, move some boxes and open the blinds which leads to a huge balcony overlooking the city. The view is spectacular, but there’s trouble on the horizon. It’s 1972, Angela Burnes is a black American woman trapped in a small fictional Latin American country called Anchuria which has just been shaken by a military coup. Nobody gets in or out and Angela has been forced to take up a housekeeping job in order to get by. This is the premise of Sunset, a first-person exploration and narrative game by Belgian developer Tale of Tales responsible for more experimental games such as The Path, Bientôt l’été and Luxuria Superbia.

Once a week, an hour before sunset, Angela will return to Ortega’s apartment to do whatever tasks he has set out for her. Ortega is still in the process of moving in and Angela can help him with unpacking and decorating. It is a nice process in which the apartment looks a bit different every time Angela returns to it. Angela only has an hour of in-game time to do these tasks which amounts to half an hour in real time. However, doing these tasks will advance time more quickly. Of course, besides these chores, Angela can explore the apartment on her own and interact with objects. Certain tasks can be done in two ways: professionally and with a distance or Angela can choose to spice it up a bit with a personal touch. Also, Ortega will leave little written notes all over the apartment to which Angela can also choose to respond to in a certain manner. Or not respond at all. Or not even perform the tasks. All of these choices will impact the nature of her relationship with Ortega. But even more than that, it could potentially impact the revolution spreading through the streets of San Bavon.

While mechanically simple, as all you do is simply press a button, it’s still a fascinating and intriguing concept. With most games offering larger and larger worlds, it’s nice to see these different takes on the concept of game worlds. A more intimate, personal approach. Re-visiting Ortega’s apartment over the course of a whole year, seeing it evolve and change and seeing Angela’s impact on it all is rewarding. There are also some snippets of the outside world delivered outside of Angela’s thoughts and Ortega’s notes. Some days you will be able to hear the gunshots and bombs going off in the city, you will be able to see helicopters and planes whizzing through the sky. It all contributes to the immersion and atmosphere very nicely. You genuinely feel that passage of time and that something is actually going on.

The writing is very good for the most part, especially regarding Angela’s monologues and her voice acting is convincing as well, but some written exchanges with Ortega feel somewhat forced and unnatural. The graphics, although technically modest, are very pleasing thanks to the wonderful art style that truly brings out that 70’s vibe despite the fact that the whole game takes place in a single apartment. I also have to single out the superb soundtrack which offers some fantastic, mostly acoustic, latin and operatic music with a few truly standout tracks. Most of the game is very silent, so when you have the option to turn on the radio or put on a record, it makes a real impact.

Unfortunately, the game suffers from severe technical issues. It runs better on beefier systems, but on more modest ones (although they still exceed the necessary requirements), it runs very poorly and oftentimes turns into a proper slide show, particularly when you play the game for longer periods. I have also experienced multiple freezes and crashes. You don’t lose any progress, but it is still very annoying. And even though by its nature the game doesn’t require any quick reflexes or anything like that, the performance issues directly impact the immersion and atmosphere which are both as crucial for this type of game as fast response time is crucial in a competitive shooter. This is unacceptable especially considering that the graphics are technically very modest and that the entire game takes place in relatively small space. It’s just a poorly optimized game that simply should not have shipped in this state. I had to turn the settings to low as well as lower the resolution to get it into a playable state and even then the performance wasn’t great. Also, the controls are a bit loose and unwieldy and when you closely approach any object, for some reason the camera distorts in a fish eye lens type of effect. I have also experienced a problem where I couldn’t interact with anything until I changed my settings from 3D to 2.5D. It’s just a whole list of serious and odd problems that simply shouldn’t be there.

Despite significant technical shortcomings, Sunset is a wholly unique and intriguing game that draws you in thanks to its captivating premise and setting, solid storytelling and exquisite sense of style and atmosphere.

6 OUT OF 10 (FAIR)

author: {'steamid': '76561197961436268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1432567813}

author: {'steamid': '76561198148028667', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1453877125}
review:
6.5/10
this was a hard one to rate

i personally really like it when games try to take on a serious issue in an imaginative approach. sunset did an excellent job of submersing the player into a world surrounded by conflict, taking an unusual passive approach. having the player in the role of a housekeeper was a brilliant way to put the player in the shoes of a civilian, even in times of war responsibilities must be kept. i wan to see more games attempt this.

however the inescapable truth was that this game was about twice as long as it really should be, to the point where i just kept asking myself "is this ever going to end?". i put in around 6 hours, and for a story like this it really should have been more like 2. and the price didn't justify the content. i see that there's some replayability in the story, but i was so exhausted by the end that i simply didn't have the time or the patience.

in summary:
this game should have been 1/2 as long and 1/4 the price
6.5/10
